When built with Go 1.15, every connection attempt results in 

```
[SYNO4] 10:08:38 WARNING: Bad certificate from ... at 172.16.33.3:22001-172.16.33.8:59376/tcp-server/TLS1.3-TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256:
   x509: certificate relies on legacy Common Name field, use SANs or temporarily enable Common Name matching with GODEBUG=x509ignoreCN=0
```

We should generate certificates with a SAN instead/in addition to the common name. However it would be great if we can connect without forcing new device IDs on everyone...

Setting the env var makes things work. However we would ideally not do that as it affects all other TLS connections as well.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a new folder on Device A, set it to "Send Only", and add some files to it.
2. Share the folder with Device B.
3. Accept the folder on Device B and set its type to "Receive Only".
4. Delete some files from the folder on Device B. The folder is now marked "Local Additions".
5. Change the folder type on Device B to "Send & Receive".
6. Both folders show "Up to Date", but the files remain deleted, which is reflected in the "Local State" on Device B.

Device A:

Device B:

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5626656/88775903-416fe680-d1c0-11ea-8f33-ab9a15a50050.png)

I should begin with saying that this might be a duplicate of #6457, but that report didn't educate me much.

I am running syncthing on Ubuntu 20.04 and parallel to a system update (before actually performing the update) I got an error from Syncthing GTK saying that the "daemon exited too fast" and wanted me to provide a path for daemon binary.

I ran syncthing from terminal and I get several panic messages. First I got a panic about Config file version (31) that was newer than the supported version (28). I followed an existing error report from the Synthing forum and switched out the Ubuntu repo version for the syncthing's own repo, uninstalled/installed and rebooted (just to be sure changes would take effect) and am now faced with a new set of errors:

### Does your log mention database corruption?

If your Syncthing log reports panics because of database corruption it is
most likely a fault with your system's storage or memory. Affected log
entries will contain lines starting with `panic: leveldb`. You will need to
delete the index database to clear this, by running `syncthing
-reset-database`.

### Include required information

Please be sure to include at least:

 - which version of Syncthing and what operating system you are using `v1.1.4-ds1, Linux (64 bit)`
 - browser and version, if applicable
 - what happened,

 - any steps to reproduce the problem. **set up syncthing, set bandwidth limits, sync two device up. see speed go through the roof, experience network congestion and router/switch crashing**

Syncthing v1.7.0 on current Arch Linux (on both clients)
I have used syncthing in the past but not for about a year, so I cant confirm if this happens in older versions.

- Syncthing Version: 1.7.0
- Browser: Any
- What Happens:
>Syncthing Settings --> Connections Tab
>Sync Protocol Listen Address: default
>Unticked/Disabled: Enable NAT Traversal, Global Discovery, Enable Relaying
>Ticked/Enabled: Local Discovery
Syncthing whilst only Local Discovery is enabled will use UPNP and commit port forwarding as If nothing was enforced (Only Local Discovery enabed) .

 - What you expected to happen instead:
Setting only Local Discovery and keeping Disabled Enable NAT Traversal, Global Discovery, Enable Relaying
Syncthing was only limited within the bounds of internal network and never acted on Its own and/or tried to open any outside ports (port forward).

This issue happens on all Syncthing 1.7.0 flavours (Linux, Android etc)
All devices are mass opening ports by means of UPNP with outside world even though ONLY Local Discovery is the only setting enabled.

Disabling Completely TCP in "Sync Protocol Listen Address" and having only quic enabled
meaning: Sync Protocol Listen Address: From default To quic://0.0.0.0:22000 or quic://10.11.10.xx 
thus specifying ONLY quick mitigates Issue of forced port forwarding/opening outside ports/use of UPNP even though "Local Discovery" is the only setting in Enabled state.

What’s the point of having a "Local Discovery" setting if It keeps port forwarding/opening outside ports/uses UPNP.

 - any steps to reproduce the problem:
>Clean Install Syncthing (I did this twice)
>Syncthing Settings --> Connections Tab
>Sync Protocol Listen Address: default
>Unticked/Disabled: Enable NAT Traversal, Global Discovery, Enable Relaying
>Ticked/Enabled: Local Discovery
>Restart If necessary Syncthing and observe for any open ports

Version 1.7.0

OS Ubuntu 18.04

ignoredFolder, child of the main <configuration> node, should have this effect:

```
    Contains the ID of the folder that should be ignored. This folder will
    always be skipped when advertised from a remote device, i.e. this will be
    logged, but there will be no dialog about it in the web GUI.
```

https://github.com/syncthing/docs/blame/main/users/config.rst#L169

I could not have it working neither by setting to a remote folder being shared with me as `<ignoredFolder>folder-id</ignoredFolder>` under `<configuration>` entry, nor by reproducing what syncthing does and setting `<ignoredFolder time="some-time-stamp" id="folder-id" label="folder-label></ignoredFolder>` under the `<device>` entry sharing that folder.

The effect is invariably that the xml entry gets removed from the config, and a new `<pendingFolder time="another-time-stamp" id="folder-id" label='folder-label"></ignoredFolder>` gets created under the `<device>` sharing that folder. This causes a warning to appear in the UI, which persists until acknowledged. 
If acknowledged, a new entry `<ignoredFolder time="still-another-time-stamp" id="folder-id" label="folder-label"></ignoredFolder>` is added to the interested `<device>` entry, which is persistent upon restart.

To summarize:

- `<configuration>...<ignoredFolder>` has no effect and gets removed upon syncthing startup.
- `<device>...<ignoredFolder time...>` has no effect and gets replaced by `<pendingFolder time...>` upon syncthing startup
- if ignore is acknowledged, syncthing creates a `<device>...<ignoredFolder time...>` entry which is apparently identical to the one set manually, but this one works and is not replaced by a `<pendingFolder>` entry.

Apparently I am out of options to ignore a folder by just editing the config.xml.

Syncthing version: 1.7.0.

OS: Ubuntu 18.04

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create empty folders A, B
2. Add to syncthing folder A, specifying staggered versioning and versioning destination folder B
3. If you click on the newly created folder Versions button, it correctly says "No data".
4. Create folder B/no_access, and, within this folder, create file B/no_access/do_not_delete
5. Set read-only and no execution o on both file and folder chmod -R 444 B/no_access
6. Versioner spits the error: 
``` 
2020-07-08 11:23:07: Versioner: error scanning versions dir lstat .../B/no_access/do_not_delete: permission denied 
```
7. Clicking on Versions button now prints "Loading data..." and nothing more.
8. If you change the B/no_access permissions to 555, everything works as expected.


The issue seems to solve itself by simply giving 555 to the no_access folder. I see not technical reason to require all subfolders of a versioning destination to be accessible to the syncthing process.

# Why do I expect this to work? 

Syncthing does versioning only for changes it receives from remote parties, but it has no way to properly do versioning on local files. if you activate versioning on one of the remote devices, versions will be safe on that remote storage. But to restore a version stored remotely, you should have some other means of connecting to the remote machine. The local syncthing instance does not allow any way of browsing and retrieving versions which are stored remotely.

So I came to the following solution, which allows to locally share versions which are produced remotely:

1. Local shares local/A with remote, SendOnly
2. Remote receives A in remote/A, ReceiveOnly, and stores versions in remote/B
3. Remote shares remote/B with local, SendOnly
4. Local receives remote/B in local/B, ReceiveOnly
5. Local specifies that the versions folder for local/A is local/B

This way, local can directly access to remote versions through the same syncthing interface, because they are shared back in local/B. In case of extreme damage, like crypto attack, you can always rever all local versions

The problem is the .stfolder marker. remote/B and local/B have dual meaning: they both are used as versioning destinations AND they are shared back with the other device. 

So they must have an .stfolder: something the Versioner does not expect. Infact, it will soon delete the .stfolder marker and this will in turn stop the sharing.

So I came to this solution: I protect the .stfolder by creating a read-only file inside of it, and making read-only also the folder. As this bug report discovered, the folder must be accessible (x). I hope alien folders/files will not stop the Versioner in the future.

Good day.  I have been Syncthing user for some years now, and never so much as a peep of trouble!  Therefore I never had occasion to thank all of you for all of your work, and perhaps even more importantly, sharing it like civilized people.  So, cheers!  :beers: 

Because I am using syncthing-android fork, I originally had lodged this issue [over there](https://github.com/Catfriend1/syncthing-android/issues/671), however Catfriend1 seems to have confirmed that this appears to be an issue in core and not his wrapper.

I copy/paste some of requested information from that thread here:

### Description of the issue

Upon starting up the wrapper, the main Syncthing process seems to crash after only a few seconds.

### Version Information
    App Version: 1.6.0.4
    Syncthing Version: not sure how to find out?
    Android Version: LineageOS 12.1 (Android 5.1.1)
    Device manufacturer: Samsung
    Device model: Galaxy s5

I did a little research into this, it looks to me like perhaps there may have been [some possibly related issues](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues?q=panic%3A+send+on+closed+channel) however after reading a bit I very quickly realized I was in over my head and I should probably just post a new issue instead.  Many of those look unresolved to me, frozen due to age, etc. but perhaps this has been fixed in the meantime, and/or someone more familiar with the codebase could refer me somewhere more relevant.

If above is not the case, I suppose you will want full logs for further troubleshooting, so let me work on sanitizing PII out of those and then I will try to find some place to upload them and share a link here.  There are also perhaps relevant clues in that other thread, but I won't repeat those here (for now).

### Does your log mention database corruption?

not applicable

### Include required information

When trying to set up a new relay server on server with IPv6-only connection, it could not join the relays pool server. It seems that the **relays.syncthing.net address has no AAAA record in DNS.** Could this record be put in the DNS? Thank you

We set some defaults in the FolderConfiguration struct definition. These are effectively only used for the initial "Sync" folder, because we only call SetDefaults in NewConfig and not when deserializing. The defaults for new folders are set in syncthingController.js. Defaults for new config options are never applied to existing folders.

Suggested cleanup:

- Some hack to make sure we apply defaults on unmarshalling a config from XML/JSON.
- A new REST API call `.../folder-defaults` that returns the default values to use to the GUI. Currently this can be just the compiled in defaults, but in the future one could imagine this being the result of compiled in defaults + user changeable ones...

#### What happened

When joining a pool `strelaysrv` always prints message about being unable to parse pool's response:

`Joined pool https://relays.syncthing.net/endpoint, failed to deserialize response: http2: response body closed`

and uses the default rejoin time instead of using the value returned by the pool

#### What is expected to happen

The relay server should properly parse the response and print a proper log message:
`Joined pool https://relays.syncthing.net/endpoint, rejoining in 48m0s`

#### How to reproduce

1. Run `strelaysrv` and wait until the wrong log message is printed

### Solution

[This PR](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/6729) fixes the issue, technical details are in the description

===Rich

We send local discovery packets on all compatible local interfaces, and can receive announcements from the same device on multiple interfaces as well. However for each received response we construct an address list based on the addresses in that announcement packet plus and the apparent source address, and then set that as the cache entry for the device in question. This means that later announcements override earlier ones, and we'll only ever see the latest announced address (highest number interface, probably).

We should keep all received addresses, or keep a separate cache per source address, or something.

If the default port is blocked (by another instance of syncthing), only the tcp and relay listeners are added in the config which is quite obvious from the code:
https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/baa38eea7a848ce693d8187e1a7a3ddb6a7fa55a/lib/config/config.go#L135-L138

I guess the issue is obvious enough to not need discussion in the forum.

I set up 5 syncthing nodes each listening to different GUI addresses. I set `globalAnnounceEnabled` and `relaysEnabled` to False. Then I let the nodes run so that they may discover each other. Almost immediately, 1 node (let's call this node 1) is fully connected to the rest of 4 nodes, with the remainder partially connected to each other. This keeps going indefinitely without extra pairing (I waited for half an hour) until I stop node 1, and also restart the remaining 4. Then another node becomes fully connected (say, node 3). I have to stop node 3 and restart the remainder again. Perhaps at any given time, a single node is absorbing all the multicast packets?

I expected the local discovery to happen immediately for the 5 nodes. But instead I had to manually restart the nodes.

This is a bug in v1.6.0-rc.4

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15955093/82379252-e040cf80-9a26-11ea-9d9c-11eb43238c39.png)

In this case the remote had all the files, nothing was present locally. As a consequence the first index update happened for the remote. This results in the incorrect metadata as in the screenshot.

The reason is that we initialize a device in metadata with the global state the first time something is added/removed from its needs. However that's too late if the device is the first to update the index: It didn't need anything before update, because there was nothing in the index, and it doesn't need anything after, as it has the global. If at some later point another device updates something such that a need is added, its needs is only then incorrectly initialized to the global state (which contains lots of stuff it actually has).

Container is behind a reverse proxy which overwrites host header to `localhost`.

Syncthing, with `setLowPriority` set to `true`, always sets its child process priority to `Below normal`, even if the parent priority is already lower than that.

To reproduce in Windows command line:

```
start /low syncthing.exe
```

Even though the parent process priority is `Idle`, the child process priority gets changed to `Below normal`.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5626656/80912106-afe60980-8d75-11ea-9670-41ad43e497d3.png)

On the other hand, with `setLowPriority` set to `false`, the child process priority remains `Idle`, following its parent priority.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5626656/80911954-a90ac700-8d74-11ea-9879-83e2419afef7.png)

I would argue that `setLowPriority` should not make Syncthing change its priority to a higher value than the one already defined on runtime.

### Version Information

Syncthing Version: v1.4.2
OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise 1607 LTSB

1. The Scan() issued by recheck during a request can hang until the pull is finished if request comes in during a pull
2. A pull can hang as long as the other side has not responded to a request
3. The other side can not respond to a request because it's trying to do a recheck which is blocked by a scan.

### Version Information

Syncthing Version: v1.4.2
OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise 2016 LTSB x64

I got a new old laptop and of course early on setup Syncthing to get all my stuff onto it. Being "smart" I setup ignores with includes early on. Well not so smart, included files aren't there yet. Should be a problem, warning is reported and that's fine, yet... the folder switched between error and no error all the time (like in a lot in a single second), maxing out cpu.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Setup a large folder on device R and share to L.
2. In the add dialog add ignores with an include to a file that doesn't exist and finish adding.

Expected:  
Warning about incorrect ignores, no activity.

Observed:  
Folder switches between error and no error rapidly, maxing out cpu.

Cause:  
Incoming indexes trigger pull and `CheckHealth` does not check ignores, but does set the error state, thus incorrectly setting it to no error. Right after that loading ignores will fail and reset the error.

Since the new upgrade check (#6385) we're getting a significant flood of upgrade requests. The problem is that some clients are stuck in restart loops, for various reasons, and hammer the upgrade server. We can of course offload this in various ways (CDNs and whatnot) but it still seems like an oversight that we should handle better...

Server side rate limiting at the HTTPS level isn't enormously useful as the main cost is in the TLS handshake to begin with.

### Version Information

Syncthing Version: v1.4.0
OS Version: Synology NAS DS416play (Linux x64)

`readWriteTransaction.removeFromGlobal` has one path where an unexpected error is handled badly. As in the global list will then be inconsistent. `checkGlobal` then cleans that up later. This surfaced because of the `withNeed` refactor, which does not ignore invalid global list entries anymore.

I intentionally do not link to sentry, as the error message added in the refactor contains filenames (will fix that too of course).

### Problem
When using staggered versioning, syncthing deletes versions withing the 30-days limit that are NOT closer than 1 day.

### Steps to reproduce
- Setup a test folder with staggered versioning, leave default settings
- Create dummy version files in the .stversions-folder named `testfile~YYYYMMDD-000000` one for each day reaching back 30 days in the past starting from now
- Restart syncthing to trigger version cleanup
- Syncthing is cleaning versions which are older than 6 days, leaving one file per week

### Expected behaviour
Syncthing leaves all versions untouched, since documentation says:
> For the first 30 days, the most recent version is kept every day.

### Version Information
Syncthing Version: v1.3.4
OS Version: Ubuntu 19.10


I have investigated the situation by looking at the code in `lib/versioner/staggered.go`. There is one digit missing in the number of seconds specifying the 30-days-interval.

```
interval: [4]interval{
    {30, 3600},       // first hour -> 30 sec between versions
    {3600, 86400},    // next day -> 1 h between versions
    {86400, 592000},  // next 30 days -> 1 day between versions  // This line is causing the issue
    {604800, maxAge}, // next year -> 1 week between versions
},
```

The number saying `592000` actually is a time period of 6.8 days only instead of the intended 30 days. The correct number would be `2592000` (Note the leading 2 which is missing).

Furthermore, the tests implemented in `lib/versioner/staggered_test.go` do not cover the issue above.

I have fixed the interval number and updated the tests and could provide a patch for that.

The "number of items to display" option at the foot of the pop-up page is (thankfully!) persistent, but so is the page number.  When the pop-up page is closed _(either with the "Close" button or by clicking on originating page "behind" the pop-up page)_, the page number that was being displayed is also persistent, so that on re-opening the pop-up _(which always displays page 1 of the refreshed list)_, the page number displayed is wrong - should be 1, of course.

**A very, VERY minor bug in a superb package!**

May I be a nuisance and - as it's related to the same part of SyncThing - mention a preference?   It would be good if the page selector could be at the top of the pop-up as well as it would save a lot of scrolling when 50 items are being displayed.

There is a problem in the latest database migration, where 

1. the block GC can run concurrently with the migration, and
2. the block GC doesn't properly use a snapshot for all its operations.

If the database is large then the block GC routine will take time and read FileInfos (none of which have block hashes yet) while the migration runs. The migration creates block list entries in the meantime. Then the block GC starts iterating block lists, without a snapshot, so it sees the new entries and deletes them because the FileInfos didn't refer to them when it saw those.

The end result is erroneously deleted block lists.

Since #6336 there's an issue where metadata gets doubled if a recalculation is deemed necessary. The reason is that we will have loaded the existing metadata, then do a recalc by adding all files without clearing it first.

Database updates are tracked by sequence number. When Syncthing starts after a crash there is a risk that the sequence number becomes out of sync and old sequence numbers are reused. This results in missed updates to peers and devices mysteriously out of sync.

Sentry Issue: [SYNCTHING-Y5](https://sentry.syncthing.net/syncthing/syncthing/issues/984/?referrer=github_integration)

### Expected behaviour
During the startup, the soft limit for the number of concurrently open files, a.k.a. `maxfiles` in `macOS`,  is increased up the hard one.
 
### Actual behaviour
During the startup, the soft limit for the number of concurrently open files, a.k.a. `maxfiles` in `macOS`, is not increased up to the hard one. 

During syncing of large directories, there are many "too many open files errors" on the `stdout`.

### Steps to reproduce
1. Set the soft limit for `maxfiles` to an extremely small number (e.g. 30) and the hard one to `unlimited`
```console
sudo launchctl limit maxfiles 30 unlimited
``` 

2. Start `syncthing`

// @calmh

When there were no changes recorded in a pull iteration, we reset all errors. However for some errors which are not recoverable through other sync actions (invalid filenames, file not available, maybe more) we do not increment the changes counter, to prevent another iteration. The errors however are still valid and should not be reset.

This was discovered in https://forum.syncthing.net/t/14-out-of-sync-items/14048

1. Open the GUI of a clean Syncthing installation. The default folder list should look like this.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5626656/67545733-3077dd80-f735-11e9-94d8-c5f00452b036.png)

2. Add a new folder pointing to the exactly same path as the "Default Folder".

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5626656/67545746-3e2d6300-f735-11e9-9174-bd42b684889a.png)

3. Remove the newly created folder using the GUI, and "rescan" the "Default Folder".

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5626656/67545755-4be2e880-f735-11e9-916e-b892a62b22bf.png)

The following error message is shown,

`Error on folder "Default Folder" (default): folder marker missing`

and the folder is not being synced anymore.

I think that it would be useful if Syncthing did not remove `.stfolder ` in a case where the same folder is still being shared in other places.

One can ask, why would you share the same folder multiple times? I personally have encountered this error when trying to share a folder from Android, and then realising that I would rather share a folder from a different device which would point at the same path. Thus, I accepted the newly shared folder, and then removed the one created previously in Android, as it was no longer needed. The result of the operation was as above.

This was just a simple mistake of mine, but I can also easily imagine valid reasons for sharing the same folder multiple times, such as having different ignore patterns for each of them, etc. In addition to that, to actually fix the problem, one needs to manually recreate the missing `.stfolder` which, depending on the operating system, may not be straightforward.

There is a data race in the replication layer that can result in a panic. The race is that we send a slice of addresses to the replication, where it gets queued in a channel, and then also the the database. The database will sort the slice while merging with an existing record, and with some bad luck this happens while the replication routine is marshalling the same slice.

As discussed in the forums (https://forum.syncthing.net/t/security-warning/13843/):

Since v1.3.0 the remote access warning considers the 'effective GUI listen address' to determine whether a warning should be shown.

As of now, this check only considers IP addresses 127./8, [::1] and unix sockets as local. Domain names/hostnames resolving to localhost such as 'localhost' are not considered local.

>  https://forum.syncthing.net/t/security-warning/13843/8, calmh said:

> Prior to 1.3.0 the warning was just based on the config value, even if overridden externally. In 1.3.0 it’s based on the config or the overridden value but the logic is unchanged. The logic never accounted for names like "localhost".
**What we should do is just get the address from the GUI listener, so we get in IP form whatever it actually ended up listening to.**

> The Syncthing admin interface is configured to allow remote access without a password.

The warning is not shown if the admin interface is listening on IPv4 or IPv6 localhost. I expect no warning in case of the unix socket, because unix sockets are less open than IPv4 or IPv6 localhost.

The following problem has come up a few times recently in the forum. The scenario is:

1. Device A creates file F, it gets synced to device B.
2. Device A ignores F and deletes it (e.g. to free up space) - device B still has the valid file.
3. Device A un-ignores F.

Observed: F gets deleted on B.

Expected: F gets synced to A.

We already have a mechanism which achieves the expected behaviour, by dropping all counters in the version from other devices when un-ignoring. So if F was ever modified by another device than A (the one where the ignore-delete-unignore cycle happened), it works, but it fails when there's no such other counters.

This issue is a companion to https://forum.syncthing.net/t/i-want-to-get-rid-of-the-syncing-status/13793/18. Basically every so often a user gets confused by Syncthing saying it's syncing, while they made sure manually that the data is already the same. The proposed solution is an additional state before "Syncing", while Syncthing is traversing the database to make a list of stuff it needs etc. Details in the forum or PR (incoming).

I have first reported this problem in the SyncTrayzor repository (https://github.com/canton7/SyncTrayzor/issues/526), as I use Syncthing mostly on Windows, but I am reporting it here too, as I believe that this is a general issue.

The problem is that if #include in .stignore is set to a non-existent file path, Syncthing continuously spams the log file with the following entries.

```
[***] **:**:** WARNING: Error on folder "***" (***-***): loading ignores: failed to load include file ***: open \\?\***: The system cannot find the path specified.
[***] **:**:** INFO: Cleared error on folder "***" (***-***)
```

Because of the log spam, Syncthing uses a lot of CPU which bogs down the whole system. If SyncTrayzor is open, it will actually use 100% of CPU and make everything unresponsive due to the console log display in SyncTrayzor itself. Without SyncTrayzor, it is just Syncthing.exe using ~50% of CPU in a mid-range 4 core system. Fortunately, the system is still responsive enough to operate, but this may not be the case on a slower device. Also, the folder status in the Web GUI keeps changing rapidly with no end to it. The only way to fix the issue seems to be to manually edit the `.stignore` file and fix the incorrect path there which as a result stops the log spam. Unfortunately, the Web GUI does not allow to edit the incorrect path directly, as the "Ignored Patterns" window is grayed out with a `Failed to load ignored patterns.` message.

Would it be possible to simply log the problem once so that the user knows of the incorrect path, and not spam the log with the error messages? Right now, even a simple spellling mistake in the #include path can cause this issue. I have not tested this in Android, but if the same thing happens there too, then stopping the log spam there will be major pain, as you would need either a 3rd party file manager or a terminal application to even be able to see and modify/delete the hidden .stignore files.

This implies inconsistencies in the model somehow?

Dialing a host's address may end up connecting (successfully) to a different host (to which a connection may already exist). 
Currently, the dialer regards this as success, and the connection is only dropped later when the device ID is checked. This prevents falling back to dialing of other addresses. 

Two possible solutions come to mind:
- Dialer should check node ID after establishing connection before returning success. 
- If a successful connection exists via an address and a different device announces the very same address (including the dialing device's addresses themselves), dialing that and assuming to reach the other device is not logical. This could be suppressed. 

Two examples in which this causes issues:
1. Two hosts behind the same NAT, one directly reachable via port forwarding, both configured to the same (default) listening port. An outside node successfully connects to the port-forwarded node, then tries to connect to the NATed node using the same external IP and port, and establishes a successful connection - but to the wrong node. 
2. Syncthing running on a NATting device itself with other nodes behind the NAT. In this case, the NATting device may be tricked into trying to connect to itself.

Pending folders are added/updated as we process them in the cluster config handling. Each update results in a config save. This is unnecessary as we already have a mechanism for deferred config save in the method in question. For a lot of folders this becomes a lot of config saving. This is not a purely theoretic issue:

https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/484fa0592e3579ed3ca1447a9cb87663c8ac49b4/lib/model/model.go#L468
```
if !to.Paused {
		// Creating the fileset can take a long time (metadata calculation)
		// so we do it outside of the lock.
		fset = db.NewFileSet(to.ID, to.Filesystem(), m.db)
	}
```

When we are scanning a folder with a large number of files, if we edit the folder property and trigger the folder restart, since the DB (maybe FileSet.Update) is being updated, the new NewFileSet here uses a new meta data object(load from db), At the same time, the unfinished GO thread writes the meta(Data lost, covered by new meta object). At this point our index exists, but the meta information is lost, which seems to be missing the file, and the file will never be scanned.

Reproduce:
1.  Add a very large number of directories
2.  In the scanning & indexing, modify the folder attributes such as the pull order.
3.  Maybe step 2 is repeated multiple times, each time a few seconds apart
4.  You can see that the number of files in the directory is inconsistent with the actual, and the lost files will never be synchronized.

Despite taking care to scrub log info from crash reports there are some places where it leaks. Specifically the panic line itself, which in some cases include folder labels or file names. These should be removed. Useful info can be logged before the actual panic, available for humans looking on the same machine.

Wrong:

```
panic(fmt.Sprintf("weird error on folder %v", folder))
```

Better:

```
l.Infoln("Weird: folder: %v", folder)
panic("weird error")
```

Borderline:

```
panic(err)
```

Hi there!

I’ve encountered an issue related to syncthing while using ksync. ksync is the tool that syncs local directory with the container in kubernetes cluster. It uses syncthing as the workhorse backend.

So we can assume that actual schema is: windows machine (C:/code) <-> linux machine (/var/www/code)

Initial sync works well, but there is an issue with file changes watcher.

When I create or change files on the linux box everything works as expected - all changes synchronized as soon as they were made. But when I try to do the same on windows strange things happen.
When I create or delete directory - it syncs instanteniously, but when I create or modify file - no changes are detected and thus no synchronization is performed. File changes are synced only when full synchronization time comes.
I’ve enabled debug logging along with file operations and filesystem watcher and it indirectly confirms my assumption: watcher reacts only to directories events.

I have about 18K files in various nested subdirs in this malfunctioning setup. When I tried to sync empty dirs - everything works as expected - file changes are detected from the both sides.

So I suppose, there is some limit in windows that prevents syncthing from functioning correct.

In linux we have some tunables like a fs.inotify.max_user_watches. Do we have something like that on windows?

Any suggestions?

Thanks!

I'm using syncthing v1.1.4
OS: Windows 10

I believe this is due to a race: We close the connection when stopping a folder, but do not wait for the connection to actually be closed before removing the folder elements from the model. So there is a small window where incoming indexes (or other things) can go through after that point. PR incoming.

Hi there! I'm having an issue when it comes to changing the GUI theme on Vivaldi/Midori, that is not replicable in Firefox. When I attempt to change the GUI theme on either of my Syncthing instances, it does not actually change, even when the page is refreshed, browser closed down entirely, or Syncthing is restarted.

However in Firefox, the change immediately takes affect and is shown. I am not sure what causes this, however I have isolated it to be a WebKit bug due to it happening on Midori and Vivaldi, of which Midori uses WebKit, and Vivaldi is based on a modified version of Chromium. 

Notably, when the theme is changed on Vivaldi, Firefox reports the theme as being the incorrect one. And changing the theme on Firefox corrects it for Firefox, but not Vivaldi.

Syncthing Version: v1.1.4, Linux (64 bit) & v1.1.4, Linux (ARM)
OS Version: Arch Linux (Anarchy Linux, 64-bit) / Arch Linux ARM (Raspberry Pi 3 Model B) 
Browser Version: Vivaldi 2.6.1566.40 (Stable channel) (64-bit)/Midori Web Browser 8.0/Firefox 67.0.3 (64-bit)

Provided below are two screenshots; the first one shows Vivaldi connected to the Raspberry Pi 3 Syncthing instance, and it showing the wrong theme. The next one shows Vivaldi connecting to the local instance of Syncthing, and it also showing the wrong theme.

I have a setup where my stdiscosrv certificate is updated by automated scripts (certbot)

To get stdiscosrv to read the certificates, I have made symbolic links under `/var/lib/syncthing/discosrv/` to the actual keypair.

When I start stdiscosrv, it tells me `"Failed to load keypair. Generating one, this might take a while..."` -- not very helpful, as it tries to write into the pem files (and the stdiscosrv user doesn't have write access to these files)...

There are two minor issues here:
1. The log should include the error upon certificate load failure.
2. Existing keypairs should not be overwritten because of a load failure (if there are no files at that location, then sure, go ahead, but don't write over existing files.)

In essense:

1. clusterconfig receiver updates config and waits for config to commit
2. config committer closes connections as part of commit, and waits for that
3. connection that is being closed waits for the dispatcher loop to exit
4. the dispatcher loop is busy calling clusterconfig in step one

(full trace attached)

Pretty sure this is new with the protocol close handling changes in 1.2.0-rc.1, so an RC issue.

[trace.txt](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/files/3290291/trace.txt)

When the Syncthing is shut down and thus the database closed, iterations may still be happening (e.g. receiving indexes). This is not safe according to the goleveldb documentation. And in general it isn't nice if Syncthing just doesn't shut down for a long while after the user asked it to do so. And this triggers the deadlock detector in RCs.

What happened: syncthing, for some folders, get stuck at 100% CPU for hours (state is `idle`)
What you expected to happen instead: CPU drops after a few minutes (when state is `idle`)
Any steps to reproduce the problem:
- set inotify limit too low
- use FSwatcher

The main issue is that there's no way to know the inotify limits to use. For instance:
- `sysctl.conf` has `fs.inotify.max_user_watches = 204800`
- directory (root folder) has `379320` directories (but only `103917` directories not ignored) and `1970011` files (but only `41029` files not ignored)

Increasing the inotify limit to 1M+ fixes the issue.

## Questions/thoughts/ideas

- does the inotify limit need to be higher than all directories (ignored + not ignored)?
- is there a way to list all files/directories to be watched? This way, we could prevent this issue by determining a correct value before increasing it with random values (here `204800` as stated in the docs doesn't help). Or perhaps just give the information in the error: `inotify limit was hit, XXX directories are to be watched (see ...)`.
- using `strace`, I've seen a lot of calls to `inotify_rm_watch`. I don't understand why? Is it because I've reached the inotify limit? After increasing the limit, there's no more calls.
- hitting the inotify limit should be reported as `INFO` or `WARNING` in the logs. I've searched a lot before understanding why my files were not in sync, enabling verbose helped a lot, because the message was clear: inotify issue (+ link to how to deal with the issue).
- I've used `sysctl -p` to update the limit right now, after editing `/etc/sysctl.conf`, perhaps it would be useful to update your docs for this very command, I think it's better as it uses the real configuration file (`/etc/sysctl.conf`), so no bad surprises on reboot.

## Thanks

Thank you for this tool, used alongside of Unison for other purposes, it's really great!

OS Version: Debian stable (Stretch), using https://apt.syncthing.net/ repository

This is a regression introduced in #5442, which ironically fixed a deadlock by introducing a new one. To reproduce run `TestReconnectSenderDuringTransfer` from the integration tests, it will time out (possibly others too).

The current systemd service file prevents startup on some systems.
Since 84fe2856591a204fcbba096cd405c9ccaef48c06, syncthing depends on multi-user.target to be finished. However, multiuser-target in turn depends on syncthing. That leads to a hanging systemctl start, at the very least when enabling syncthing via

`$ sudo systemctl enable syncthing@MY_USER.service`

[As discussed on the forums](https://forum.syncthing.net/t/systemd-trouble-after-v1-1-1-upgrade/13201/5), a revert may be necessary (or a better solution).

Detected in https://forum.syncthing.net/t/pull-no-such-file-error/13139/22

This is a super corner case:

1. Program allocates space and thus sets modtime.
2. Syncthing scans.
3. Program does the actual change on disk, that only affects the last block of the file.
4. Peer requests that last block.

Result: Block index too high error.
Expected: File gets force rescanned.

Syncthing Version: v1.1.1
OS Version: Windows 7 & OSX 10.9 & Ubuntu 18.04

# What I did

I've set up Syncthing on three machines - my desktop and my laptop that I need to sync files between, and a dedicated AWS EC2 instance for backups and so that stuff still get synced if both of my computers aren't on at the same time. (They usually aren't.)

First I set it up on the AWS instance, then I set it up on my Macbook. I set things synchronizing and after a couple of hiccups I had a couple folders duplicated on the dedicated server. (Per hiccups: Syncing slows down massively when the GUI is open?? I mean, I get why this could happen, but some kind of notice in the GUI would have been really helpful, I spent like an hour troubleshooting why network would be having problems that could explain the slow transfer rate when in fact it all had to do with the GUI.)

Then I set it up on Windows. I have been using Dropbox up to now, and the reason I'm setting up Syncthing is because Dropbox is ending support for my Macbook's OS. This means that all the files I need to sync were already being synchronized by Dropbox. I shared the smaller of the two folders I've been trying out with Syncthing between all the devices and everything was great. Syncthing recognized right away that everything was already synchronized. [Following this discussion in the forum](https://forum.syncthing.net/t/removed-and-then-re-added-subfolder-triggers-deleted-and-then-modified-events/12857)

When a file or folder is deleted, it is marked as `deleted: true` in the database. An event with `data.action: 'deleted'` is also emitted.

When this file or folder is created again OR a file or folder with same name and path is created, it is marked as `deleted: false` in the database and an event with `data.action: 'modified'` is emitted. This is **counterintuitive**, emitting `data.action: 'added' `seems more consistent.

This issue is in reaction to https://forum.syncthing.net/t/pretty-drastic-amount-of-writes-when-doing-initial-scan/12850 and a regression in #5441. Already since before that regression batch writes are flushed to db based on number of entries in the batch. That's okish, if entries are of the same size. However since #5441 that's no longer true, as full file infos are written in the same batch as e.g. blockmap entries. Before file infos were flushed after 64 batched items, blockmap entries after 1000, now it's 64 for both together.

I propose to use `func (b *Batch) Dump() []byte` to check the byte length of the batch and decide whether to flush based on that. Dump does not copy the data, so it should be efficient. Handwaving conversion of previous limits (64*fileinfo = 64 * (2000 blocks + more) = 64 * (8kB + 8kB) = 1MB) increasing a bit due to Moore gets me to 8MB limit. Any other (potentially more informed) propositions?

# Context

The version used is [syncthing-linux-amd64-v1.0.0.tar.gz](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/releases/download/v1.0.0/syncthing-linux-amd64-v1.0.0.tar.gz). Displayed version on the Web interface: v1.0.0, Linux (64 bit).
- Tablet on Android 7.0, with Syncthing taken from the Play store. Displayed version on the Web interface: v0.14.51, android (ARM)

I have one shared folder, let's call it `share`, for these two nodes. No specific configuration besides a limit of 1GB of free space. Since I am far from reaching it, I assume it is out of topic and we can assume a default configuration of the shared folder.

As of the storage:
- Tablet stores on the internal storage.
- PC stores on an external hard drive in NTFS (to be accessible on Windows too)

Both nodes were continuously running during the whole operation, so they could sync at any time.

# What happened

Yesterday on the tablet, I added 3 files (several hundreds of MB each) to `share`, and then quickly moved 2 of them to `share/myFolder`. Today I checked my PC, and it displays that the folder is up to date (which is true when I look at the content) but on the 2 moved items 1 is listed as failed item. The message displayed is:
> peers who had this file went away, or the file has changed while syncing. will retry later

# What you expected to happen instead

I would expect Syncthing to be aware of file moving. So rather than considering the `share` and `share/myFolder` files as different, it should consider them as the same, and thus don't expect to have the `share` one when it already has the `share/myFolder` one.

In other words, although the error might happen during the state transition, now it should have figured it was a move and the error should have disappeared already.

# Any steps to reproduce the problem

I assume these are the steps:
- Create a shared folder between 2 nodes A & B
- Create a subfolder
- Wait for both nodes to be sync
- Add a file F in A
- Wait for B to see there is F
- Move F to subfolder before it is fully sync on B (F should be big enough or upload should be limited to ensure it is not too fast)
- Let syncing until B fully retrieves F in the subfolder
- B should still display the error for the missing F in the root folder

Since we added reporting of scan failures to the GUI, I get things like this: This popped up when I deleted the test file and it got reported by fs notifications. "no such file" is expected under the circumstances, so I think we're being too eager to report an error somewhere in the stack. Also, the scan failure doesn't go away until you do a manual rescan *and reload the GUI*.

There's an issue with the event system which can cause what is effectively a deadlock during normal operations. It's not a logical deadlock, it's just that sending events can end up taking forever, which blocks other things. We often send events while holding other locks, which makes it worse.

Specifically, when an event listener no longer polls for events the Log() call will block for 150 ms per non-polling listener. If there are several dead listeners this can add up, and it blocks other Log() calls during this time as well due to needing to hold the lock. 

There are a couple of places where we can end up with dead event listeners. The [watch aggregator can exit but never unsubscribes](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/c9349183478321cc434b92cd8d7dc9bfefed82db/lib/watchaggregator/aggregator.go#L135-L162). But more seriously, anything that 1) ceases to process events 2) unsubscribes, perhaps as part of a defer, causes this issue. For example, [sendIndexes](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/c9349183478321cc434b92cd8d7dc9bfefed82db/lib/model/model.go#L1823-L1861).

The reason for the latter is that once we stop reading events, the Unsubscribe() can take effectively forever. There might be a thousand event senders producing events quite frequently (for example, lots of folders which are scanning on a short interval). These all compete for the mutex which must be held to unsubscribe. As each of these calls can take over a second and there are thousands and thousands of them waiting for the lock, the odds that our Unsubscribe() call actually gets to acquire the lock in reasonable time are slim.

I have a test that reproduces this sad situation.

I see several potential solutions; first of all we must ensure that every subscribe is matched by an unsubscribe. Then;

1. We can use a [priority lock](https://github.com/platinummonkey/priority-lock) to prioritize Subscribe()/Unsubscribe() over Log(). This works nicely in my testing, because the unsubscribe gets to happen ahead of the queue and then everything else is quick again.

2. We can use BufferedSubscriptions() everywhere, as these continue reading the actual event stream in the background until the unsubscribe has actually gotten through.

3. We can make the event system more lossy, putting the burden to keep up with the events more on the receiving side. A normal Subscription already has a buffered channel; we could simply skip the timeout handling in Log() and use a non-blocking send.

I think we should do number 1 at minimum, and possibly number 3. In the cases where we expect many events and have to catch 'em all, that's what the buffered subscription is for.

As a motivator, here's a massive backtrace showing the problem (on 0.14.48).

[backtrace.txt](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/files/2673301/backtrace.txt)

The WebUI updates based on changes made to settings by the user before those changes have been processed by the server. This causes the user to assume the changes have been saved when they are not.

Background: I am running Syncthing on a slow machine. Whenever I make changes to folder settings, the WebUI changes to reflect these, giving the impression that the changes were made and have been saved. However, the changes are sent to the server asynchronously and on a slow machine it may take a very long time for them to be processed (separate bug filed for that). If I leave the webpage, the changes may not be applied on the server even though I was led to believe they were.

Workaround: leave the WebUI page open for a long time (half an hour should do) and hope the requests will get processed at some point, then refresh to see the real state.

### Version Information

Syncthing Version: v0.14.54, Linux (ARM)
OS Version: Linux 4.14.69+ on Raspberry PI
Browser Version: Tested with Firefox and Chrome; issues appears to be server-side.

Files deleted on one node will not be deleted on the second node.

### Steps to reproduce the problem ###

There are two nodes A (Win10) and B (Synology DS415+) with a shared folder, everything is "Up to date". A: Ignore permissions = NO / B: Ignore permissions = YES 

I added a file "P.JPG" from A into the folder and waited for the sync to complete. Both nodes show "Up to date".

When I now delete the file on node A, the corresponding file "P.JPG" on node B will not be deleted.

https://forum.syncthing.net/t/0-14-52-file-deletion-issues/12436

Here are some pictures: both files on Synology File Manager 
![screenshot filestation](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17129357/48378466-fe5e9e80-e6d0-11e8-9328-0b122814e9a6.png)

both files with ssh/ls:
![screenshot ssh](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17129357/48378477-061e4300-e6d1-11e8-87c5-d9ab00a7da4a.png)

syncthing on B after deleting both files
![screenshot synology folder](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17129357/48378486-10d8d800-e6d1-11e8-9f78-a595d245dbc6.png)

the error message

On my Ubuntu machine where syncthing is running (from the snap) I was running `snappy-debug.security scanlog` (a tool snap packagers use to identify confinement problems) for another program, and noticed it complain about syncthing. Full log below.

It looks like the syncthing application is trying to call out to the /bin/ip and /sbin/route commands. These are not bundled in the snap, and confinement prevents them from running. You may need to bundle them via a `stage-packages` stanza in the snapcraft.yaml. `ip` appears to originate in the `iproute2` package and `route` is in the net-tools package. Hope that helps.

Syncthing Version:  v0.14.51, Linux (64 bit)
OS Version: Ubuntu 18.04

```
= AppArmor =
Time: Oct 24 19:50:59
Log: apparmor="DENIED" operation="exec" profile="snap.syncthing.syncthing" name="/sbin/route" pid=18198 comm="syncthing" requested_mask="x" denied_mask="x" fsuid=1000 ouid=0
File: /sbin/route (exec)
Suggestions:
* adjust snap to ship 'route'
* adjust program to use relative paths if the snap already ships 'route'

= AppArmor =
Time: Oct 24 19:50:59
Log: apparmor="DENIED" operation="exec" profile="snap.syncthing.syncthing" name="/bin/ip" pid=18199 comm="syncthing" requested_mask="x" denied_mask="x" fsuid=1000 ouid=0
File: /bin/ip (exec)
Suggestions:
* adjust snap to ship 'ip'
* adjust program to use relative paths if the snap already ships 'ip'
```

Here's how I could reproduce the issue:
1. Copy https://github.com/Martchus/syncthingtray/blob/master/connector/testfiles/testconfig/config.xml to an empty directory
2. Start `syncthing -gui-address=http://localhost:4001 -gui-apikey=syncthingtestinstance -home=/dir/with/config -no-browser -verbose`

* The problem only occurs if device `MMGUI6U-WUEZQCP-XZZ6VYB-LCT4TVC-ER2HAVX-QYT6X7D-S6ZSG2B-323KLQ7` is actually reachable in my local network.
* This device in my local network has actually a different device ID than stated in the configuration file. That 'misconfiguration' comes from the fact that https://github.com/Martchus/syncthingtray/blob/master/connector/testfiles/testconfig/config.xml is really just intended for testing Syncthing Tray's code and no actual connection is supposed to happen.
* I have another Syncthing instance running at the same time which is configured correctly and it can connect to the mentioned device in my local network.

Comments from @imsodin via IRC:

This is an issue with #5084 (fixing #2291) thus .51 RC material.

Unknown folders announced by a remote aren't actually added to the newly created config fields, thus won't show up in the UI.

### Reproducer

1. Add and share new folder on remote.
2. Make sure the "Unexpected folder..." message appears on the local device, i.e. the folder was announced.

Result: No new folder notification and no `PendingDevices` field in the config.

Expected: Both of the above.

### Cause

The function `wrapper.AddOrUpdatePendingFolder` modifies the copy returned by the for loop instead of the actual config member. (It is done correctly in `wrapper.AddOrUpdatePendingDevice` - little bit embarrassing I didn't catch it in review).

### Environment:

Two discovery servers, one running v0.14.46@armhf/Raspbian, the other running on v0.14.49@x86_64/Centos7. I occasionally see in the logs:
```
stdiscosrv[11974]: Replication read size: read tcp 172.31.3.1:19200->192.168.4.1:50316: i/o timeout
```
or
```
stdiscosrv[12505]: Replication write: write tcp 192.168.4.2:40726->192.168.8.1:19200: write:broken pipe
stdiscosrv[12505]: Supervisor main: main: Failed service 'replicationSender("192.168.8.1:19200")' (1.000000 failures of 5.000000), restarting: true, error: "{replicationSender(\"192.168.8.1:19200\") replicationSender(\"192.168.8.1:19200\")} returned unexpectedly", stacktrace: [unknown stack trace]
```
After closer investigation, it seem that the culprit is this line: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/2c9d96375bb5e3a8dcf7840412462182ce0b9433/cmd/stdiscosrv/replication.go#L248-L252

Namely, unless there is enough traffic on the wire, the replication connection will be torn down. What is more, the is no reconnect on the other side: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/2c9d96375bb5e3a8dcf7840412462182ce0b9433/cmd/stdiscosrv/replication.go#L105-L110

So basically, if there is not enough traffic in the replication servers, the replication will not work.

I think the solution would be to not to set a read timeout in https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/2c9d96375bb5e3a8dcf7840412462182ce0b9433/cmd/stdiscosrv/replication.go#L245 - i.e. wait indefinitely (preferable), or handle reconnects on the sending side (more work), or implement heartbeats in the replication protocol (quite a bit of work).

Let me know if this sounds reasonable. I can prepare a patch.

On Windows, if a file is modified but the file size remains the same, the file system watcher doesn't detect the change. Syncthing won't sync the changes to the file until the next folder scan.

I can reproduce this issue by opening a text file with Notepad, changing one of the characters (leaving the length of the file the same) and saving the file. With the `NOTIFY_DEBUG` environment variable enabled, the Syncthing logs don't show a change having been detected (I would expect to see 'dispatching notify.FileActionModified').

I suspect this issue can be fixed by including [`FILE_NOTIFY_CHANGE_LAST_WRITE`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/api/WinBase/nf-winbase-readdirectorychangesw#FILE_NOTIFY_CHANGE_LAST_WRITE) in the filter passed to `ReadDirectoryChanges` in [`watcher_readdcw.go`](https://github.com/syncthing/notify/blob/master/watcher_readdcw.go). This will generate an event when the last-write time of a file is changed.

What happens is that invalid/ignored files are not added at the top of the global list, even if they are of the newest version. That's fine, but the code that keeps the need bucket up to date does assume that only changes at the beginning of the list are relevant, which isn't true in this case.

Lets assume I'm on 0.14.45. I upgrade to 0.14.48 and two database migrations are applied. But 0.14.48 has some sort of bug that I can't tolerate and I roll back to 0.14.45. Things are fine.

Then 0.14.49 comes out and I upgrade. The migrations will be applied again, but there's already a bunch of new indexes and stuff in place. Some of those keys will probably be overwritten correctly, some will remain from the previous migration run and be totally wrong at this point. Chaos ensues.

We should wipe the key space for what we're creating in a migration, before creating it.

---

Not all migrations will be backwards compatible and then the downgrade step itself will fail. That's a different issue, and probably fine.

This happened on a folder restart, when the model already removed the ignore patterns but the folder loop was still running. This is possible due to `select` choosing a random option, not necessarily the canceled context. This could also lead to parallel pulling and scanning, if a folder is restarted during pulling, because the pull operation can keep running (processing deletes) after the folder was stopped.

I'll propose a mechanism to wait for the folder to "clean up" in the model shortly.

When there are lots of devices and/or folders (in the hundreds), the GUI becomes unusably slow, beyond what you'd expect from just having a cumbersome amount of GUI elements.

From my initial analysis something like the following is what happens.

- We load the GUI Javascript and stuff.
- We load the system config.
- Based on the config we populate the initial `$scope` with the folders and devices, and Angular starts rendering the boxes for each.
- For each folder and device we fire a bunch of HTTP requests to get the initial status, completion, etc.
- When a response comes in we do a bunch of work to update the stuff in `$scope` which causes Angular to re-render all of the things.

Given *k* HTTP requests times *n* folders each causing a re-render of *n* folder boxes this is essentially O(n²) on folders and/or devices and the rendering takes ages.

There appears to be a solution in Angular 1.3+ `$applyAsync` that delays rendering until fixed tick and thus batches handling the responses. We're currently on 1.2. Upgrades have historically been painful.

0.14.47 changed the looks of Folder properties. There are tabs now, and  the "Save" button seems to save what happened on all tabs, not just the current one.

One of the tabs is "Ignore patterns". When you open Folder properties, it initially reads "Loading…", then is replaced by what it actually found in .stignore.

On a slow machine, you might open Folder properties to tweak Rescan interval, for example, change what you see fit and hit the "Save" button before it has time to load .stignore properly. In this case the web interface seems to think that "Loading…" is in fact your new ignore patterns and OVERWRITES .stignore WITH "Loading…"!!!

As the title says, Syncthing recreates or tries to recreate the directories for deleted or missing Folders. I have two examples below. They are similar in the sense that the Folder path and folder marker are gone when the issue happens.

## Example 1
### What happened
- I had a Folder added to Syncthing residing at path `/Volumes/foo/bar/baz` which is on an external hard drive. Just to clarify, the folder marker is `/Volumes/foo/bar/baz/.stfolder`.
- I decided to move it to somewhere else but also decided to deal with updating the path of the Folder later.
- I paused the Folder in Syncthing UI.
- I moved the folder to its new location. `foo` directory doesn't exist in `/Volumes` anymore.
- [issue] When I restart Syncthing it creates the `/Volumes/foo/bar/baz` directory structure while the Folder is still paused.
- [expected] If I resume the Folder I get `folder marker missing` error

### What I expected to happen
- Syncthing should not create `foo/bar/baz` directories in `/Volumes`.

### Steps to reproduce
- Create a few directories inside each other on an external drive (I am not sure if the drive being external is necessary, that is just how my setup is)
- Add the deepest directory to Syncthing as a Folder
- Pause the Folder
- Delete the whole directory structure up to the root of the external drive
- Restart Syncthing
- Observe. Sometimes Finder doesn't update itself so closing/reopening the Finder window might be necessary.

### Screen recording (8.1 MB)
![folder recreation bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/732128/39232569-9305e974-4822-11e8-8f28-825bae7b7874.gif)

## Example 2
### What happened
- I have an encrypted directory that I mount to /Volumes/EncFS, which is also added to Syncthing. Just to clarify, the folder marker is `/Volumes/EncFS/.stfolder`.
- When I restart my computer, that encrypted directory is not mounted automatically.
- [issue] Syncthing start automatically and gives me `Creating directory for foobar: mkdir /Volumes/EncFS: permission denied ` error. (`foobar` is a directory that is in `/Volumes/EncFS` when the encrypted directory is mounted.)
- [expected] I also get `folder marker missing` error

### What I expected to happen
- Syncthing should not try to create `EncFS` or `EncFS/foobar` directories in `/Volumes`.

### Steps to reproduce
- Create an encrypted directory
- Mount the encrypted directory
- Add some files/directories in the mount point
- Add the mount point to Syncthing as a Folder
- Share that Folder with other Syncthing instances and make sure they are synched
- Restart computer.
- Open Syncthing UI and observe the errors.

#### Version Information
Syncthing Version: v0.14.46, macOS (64 bit)
OS Version: macOS High Sierra 10.13.4 (17E202)

- Edit ignore patterns and add `#include global-ignores`
- Save changes
- Observe that #include file is not used for ignores and that Ignore Patterns GUI pane is empty.

When doing the host check, syncthing calls addressIsLocalHost(), which appears to be too restrictive.  There are valid localhost addresses that are failing this test.  For example, 127.5.6.7.  In fact 127.0.0.0/8 is defined as being local to the machine.

My use case is this:

To avoid more and more obscure local port forwarding when I SSH to a remote box (e.g. ssh -L 28384:localhost:8384), I put specific localhost entries in /etc/hosts, such as
    127.5.6.7 myremotehost.lo 
and then I can put this in my ~/.ssh/config:
    Host myremotehost.com
        LocalForward myremotehost.lo:8384 localhost:8384
and then navigate to
    http://myremotehost.lo:8384

This breaks because addressIsLocalHost() doesn't think 127.5.6.7 is a valid local host, and I get the Host Check Error.

I can disable the check, but that weakens security.  It would be better to have the function fixed.

I'm not a Go programmer.  I can see in GitHub where the code is called, and where the test function is.  Perhaps it's a standard library function.  I tried googling and searching the golang API site, but I can't find it.  Sorry I can't be more help.

bug happens when two of your devices connect to the same relay, as the next dial time is decided per address, which happens to be the same for two devices connected to the same relay.

When run in a subshell, on Linux, i.e.

```
jb@acro:~ $ cat run.sh 
#!/bin/bash

syncthing -no-browser -no-restart

jb@acro:~ $ ./run.sh 
```

Syncthing won't get and exit due to a Ctrl-C. If the last line is `exec syncthing ...` it's all good as then there is no intermediate shell.

Another workaround is to *not* use `-no-restart`, as the monitor process will then handle this correctly, getting the Ctrl-C and passing the signal to its child. And honestly this is the expected way to run when running "interactively" anyway.

This is due to the process group juggling in c554ffcc, 91210cbb, c2119c9e. The controlling terminal sends the signal to the foreground process group, which in this case is just bash (as we move away into our own process group). 

BSD, Mac, etc don't suffer from this as they have sane thread implementations where we don't need to do tricks with the process group.

A potential "fix" could be to have the monitor process do this instead, by using runtime.LockOSThread, setting the niceness for the current thread, then syscall.ForkExec to spawn the real syncthing from that thread, inheriting the priority. I'm not very fond of moving stuff into the monitor.

Or we could just remove the hack and tell Linux users to set the niceness themselves. Or maybe just let this be a known issue forever.

Potentially multiple issues, almost surely related to #4584.

Off the top of my head I can see one issue with directories that have been renamed case-only on case insensitive systems: whereas previously we would see the files just fine, we would now lockstep-walk the database vs the filesystem, potentially note that the directory we expected didn't happen, and mark everything below as deleted. That is, we see `foo/` when walking and conclude that`Foo/**` which is in the database has been deleted. This propagates to some other device where the deletes happen, and it's a self fulfilling prophesy.

When pulling a zero block into a newly created sparse file we do nothing. Unfortunately, "nothing" includes not marking the block as handled. When the file then reaches the final stage of operations it looks like it still has those blocks outstanding to handle, so it is not closed and finalized. With many files hitting this condition of after a sufficiently long time the process will run out of file handles.

```
jb@unu:~ $ syncthing 
[monitor] 22:43:40 INFO: Starting syncthing
[SYNO4] 22:43:40 INFO: syncthing v0.14.43-rc.1+8-gdb03562d "Dysprosium Dragonfly" (go1.9.2 darwin-amd64) jb@unu.kastelo.net 2018-01-05 18:11:09 UTC

That 500 error shouldn't happen either.

There is at the time of writing no newer version, which is what the upgrade check should return.

See https://forum.syncthing.net/t/utf8-encoding-conflict-with-another-file/11122.

It turns out that ZFS doesn't do any normalization when storing files,
but does do normalization "as part of any comparison process".

In practice, this seems to mean that if you LStat a normalized filename,
ZFS will return the FileInfo for the un-normalized version of that
filename.

This means that our test to see whether a separate file with a
normalized version of the filename already exists was failing, as we
were detecting the same file.

I'm in the process to build up a backup (syncthing). The database is growing.

### Version Information

Syncthing Version: 0.14.42
OS Version: Ubuntu 17.10

When a file is deleted from the slave first, and then from the read-only master. It disappeared and later existed again in the "out of sync" list on the master. I feel it should be excluded permanently in the list. My steps to reproduce: - Create 4 files 0, 1, 2, 3 on the master node. Set the folder in the master to be "send only" - Do an initial synchronization - Delete 2, 3 on the slave - Rescan on the slave and synchronize - Delete 1, 2 on the master - Pause and resume on the master (optional) - The "out of sync" list shows only 3 - Later (I tried 3 times) - In 2 attempts, the final list showed after a pause and a resume - In 1 attempt, I paused and resumed several times before seeing the count of "out of sync" list to be 2 - Now we have 0, 3 on the master and 0 on the slave - Eventually the "out of sync" list shows 2 and 3. Since 2 is already deleted from the master and the slave, I think it shouldn't appear here I tried to restart Syncthing or the operation system, but the problem persisted Screenshots from the master: ### Version Information Syncthing Version: v0.14.42 OS Version: Master: Windows7 (64-bit) Slave: Android 7.1 I also encountered a similar issue with Master: Android 4.4 Slave: Android 7.1

Something is buggy here. Two machines, A and B. A is receive only and has ignore patterns: B is newly set up and has no ignore patterns. I browse a few files on B, creating .DS_Store files. Now, on A: Hitting "override changes" deletes the ignored .DS_Store files... v0.14.42, gut feeling says #4460 is to blame somehow.

If the truncate call fails after we've opened a temp file we will return with an error, leaving the temp file fd open.

Previously directories matching the current input were displayed in a dropdown box below the entry field when creating a new folder in the web UI. This does no longer work in general (it does e.g. work when entering just "/").
Cgo strictness is increased, resulting in Zillode/notify#9. Needs to be fixed for Go 1.10 release, preferably sooner rather than later.

Repro:

1. Create `dir/file` and make sure they are synced between devices A and B.
2. Change ownership/permission for `dir` on device A such that the user syncthing is running as is no longer able to access `dir` (e.g. `sudo chown root:root dir && sudo chmod 700 dir`).
3. Hit the rescan button on device A and wait for "changes" to propagate to B.

Result: `dir/file` gets deleted from device B.

Expected: Some kind of error or at least "nothing" (see #4480), but certainly not deletion of the file on the remote.

Origin of bug:  
Lstat returning any error is considered equal to file having been deleted: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/master/lib/model/model.go#L1989

Possible solutions:  
Maybe this can be handled with stricter checking of the error returned by Lstat. If we do this, I believe we need to add `IsNotExist(err) bool` to the filesystem interface to make sure all filesystem implementations are compatible with this check.  
The following idea doesn't actually work (we also detect "ordinary" deletes this way).<strike>It might be both more consistent and performant to drop these lstat checks and replace them by comparing the new file info with the one it has replaced. Thus cases like replacing a dir with a file can still be detected and handled, while the case described here wont result in data loss.</strike>  
Another possibility would be to implement #4480 and skip the current lstat tests on paths that failed to be scanned.

Again/still/always... This time when adding a new device and doing the initial sync. I think this makes it relatively easy to reproduce. This is a long lived folder, so the first million or so index entries are for sure for deleted files. While these are processed it looks like this:

![screen shot 2017-12-05 at 11 53 45](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/125426/33604363-f935841a-d9b5-11e7-9ea2-763093407833.png)

Note both length of the progress bar and the bytes remaining to sync. Once it starts processing actual missing files it becomes normal.

ST crashed after waking the system from sleep with this error:
`panic: interface conversion: *errors.errorString is not net.Error: missing method Temporary`

The setup is rather unremarkable, no altered advanced config.; restart on wake is set to default (enabled)

Log:
https://gist.github.com/anonymous/0a4582c93581903cb79c1a76d6d3b07e

### Version Information

Syncthing Version: v0.14.40 running under SyncTrayzor v.1.1.18
OS Version: Win10x64

### What happened

On Windows, an external versioning command path requires \\\\ (two backslashes) instead of single \\.
This sounds a bit unnatural and the instruction in [the doc page](https://docs.syncthing.net/users/versioning.html#example-for-windows) doesn't work.

### Any steps to reproduce the problem.

For example, if the command is set like this:

![iss](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22708232/33383288-47d8731a-d566-11e7-91f6-c5bfbede64c9.png)
then I get this error log:
`[VQZ3H] 2017/11/30 00:25:31.724302 rwfolder.go:1675: INFO: Puller (folder "\"sttest\" (vu3ga-eo2y9)", file "test.txt"): delete file: exec: "C:UserstestusrDesktopext.bat": file does not exist`

OK the path isn't recognized correctly with single \ for some reason.

I found two workarounds:
- use \\\\ instead of \\
- use / (this is uncommon for windows)

[JWK46] 2017/11/19 10:52:01.471001 structs.go:191: DEBUG: dialing AGR6NY2 tcp://85.216.59.171:22000 outcome %!v(PANIC=runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference) dial tcp 85.216.59.171:22000: i/o timeout

```

Note it filtering out one address, then dialling `tcp://85.216.59.171:22000` apparently twice. There is a race in the parallel dialler.

This is very low importance, it just came up with a recent report of connection issues:

Logging like `l.Infoln(err)` leads to errors like 

```
[NPNSQ] 22:22:01 INFO: set tcp 192.168.178.24:6736->192.168.178.20:22000: protocol not available
```

whose origin and context are not immediately clear. As this is user facing information, it should contain a minimum of information. In the example of the tcp listener this could be in line with existing logging:

```
			l.Infoln("Listen (BEP/tcp): failed to set options:", err)
```

The alternative is to downgrade it to debug logging level, where the context is evident from file names and line numbers. In the case of the tcp listener, [similar failures are on different levels](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/master/lib/connections/tcp_listen.go#L105). Is this on purpose or should all of them be either debug or info level?

Currently the folder puller will pause for a minute if it isn't making progress anymore. This happens for example if you have symlinks in your folder which will fail as they are not supported.

This request is for the puller to completely stop if all items that would be left are either not supported or fail so that it does not unnecessary run again and again and cause CPU spikes.

Syncthing Version: v0.14.37
OS Version: fedora rawhide/28/s390x
go version: 1.9beta2

A couple of times I've lost my data because i hooked up Syncthing to an empty folder and instead of pulling the latest copy of what's in the cloud everything gets wiped from the cloud... Why would this happen? Well if you're relocating to a new directory. Syncthing provides no function to do this, so i cook it up by editing the XML. (So yeah it's really my own fault and now I'm here)
So i change the old path to the new path and then restart Syncthing. Synthing then proceeds to wiping the data across all devices.

You could argue that deleting everything is subjective to the users decisions.
Plis "rm –rf /" said no one ever.

The failsafe is simple. If Syncthing detects that your "new change" includes deleting everything from the root. Simply stop pushing updates and await a user response from the control panel. Mark the folder in yellow saying "Confirmation Required"."Please confirm whether you would like to download latest copy or, clear out the directory [Download All] [Delete All]"


That is all, thanks for a great project!

It happens when I try to delete a shared "folder" from the web UI, with a syncthing daemon running in background.

After updating to 0.14.37, all root folders which are referenced by symlink result in "Failed initial scan (rw) of...". Verified by creating two new sync folders, one referencing an actual folder's location, the other a symlink to a folder on another drive.

A current workaround of the problem is to set the path directly to the folder (no symlink).

Syncthing Version: v0.14.37
OS Version: Windows 10

I tried building the new syncthing release on fedora, but I hit this error in the tests - which hasn't been happening with earlier versions. Since it's only happening on the armv7hl build VM (which is the slowest), I suspect it is timing related / a race condition.

```
+ go test -compiler gc -ldflags '' github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/versioner
--- FAIL: TestTrashcanCleanout (0.01s)
	trashcan_test.go:69: empty directory should have been removed
FAIL
FAIL	github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/versioner	3.063s
```

Syncthing Version: v0.14.37
OS Version: fedora rawhide/28
go version: 1.9beta2

Let's say I have three devices (1 linux [A] + 2 android [B, C] if this is relevant). All devices are in sync. I switch off syncthing on all 3 devices.

1. I edit file X on device B, then C, then A. So file X has changed on all 3 devices.
2. I switch on syncthing on B, C, A.
3. I wait
4. After a while, the version of file X edited last on device A is propagated to B and C. There is not copy of the old version of X on B and C indicating a synchronization conflict.

I personally would expect to end up with at least two files indicating a synchronization conflict.

Is the situation describe in step 4 the expected outcome? Are my expectations about how synchting works wrong?

Discovered in:
https://forum.syncthing.net/t/data-path-vanished-error-box-appearing-folder-stops-sync-ing-megabug/10340/5

To reproduce, just edit any folder without a label and the default path will appear instead of the previous one.

All symlinks in our shares disappeared:

https://gist.github.com/koma85/8901a0f56fa26196bacb5b1fed7b46ea

This happened after the automatic update as you can see from our log

I just filed https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=713159
This affects Syncthing, because there is a heading inside the button. This causes chrome to think that the accessibility tree should be flattened, and therefore, the accordian no longer has sections marked with headings.

It is not necessarily necessary to have a button here at all for accessibility purposes, because aria-expanded can directly be put on a heading. This will cause a screen reader to report something like "heading level three collapsed my device 1." If this was a feature request in the past, or a user has requested buttons be placed on each element which is to be expanded and collapsed, it should be noted that the heading should probably be placed outside the button to prevent issues such as this. 
Thanks
