Usecase:
I share a few larger, slow changing folders from inside a truecrypt container. I use a high rescan interval, because I use to work with the data and I dont want to sync before I am done. (work is ususally below 10 min, like copying pictures inside and renaming them.) I set the other side to "versioning" and I dont want copies of all that renaming on that side.
After mounting, I usually click "rescan all" to get them from stopped to alive.

what happend:
With the change from v0.14.26 to v0.14.27, the functionality of the "Rescan all" Button changed.
Before: 
Stopped Folders would be checked if they are "alive" again
Now:
Stopped Folders are skipped during the "Rescan all" function

Folders can only get "alive" again, if the rescan interval is due.

what you expected to happen instead:
Stopped Folders would be checked if they are "alive" again

any steps to reproduce the problem:
unmount a shared folder 
start Syncthing
rescan the folder > status is "Stopped"
mount folder again
press "Rescan all" or "Rescan" on the individual folder. (Same effect: No effect)

I noticed today that the syncthing.log in Syncthing’s home directory was getting very big (> 15GB). I could not open the log anymore. Because of that I stopped Syncthing, deleted the log and started Syncthing again. Now I could see that the following messages was repeated very very often:
[FCKL4] 09:47:49 INFO: Couldn't fetch release information: Get https://upgrades.syncthing.net/meta.json: dial tcp 46.101.130.230:443: connectex: Der Zugriff auf einen Socket war aufgrund der Zugriffsrechte des Sockets unzulässig.

A few weeks or months ago I disabled automatic upgrades by setting autoUpgradeIntervalH to zero. After I changed the value to 999999 and restarted Syncthing the problem was gone.

Well, not the entire service, but the connection loop. Basically, if the other side isn't responding the connection attempt will take "forever" (I don't know how long, but at the very least it stops at that point for minutes). This blocks connecting to other devices and addresses.

Trivial to reproduce:

Start up s1 and s2 (`cd test; syncthing -home h1` etc) and let them connect. Restart one side. The other will time out the connection after ~ eight minutes - this is expected, as we don't have any `RST`-equivalent in this protocol (although I think the interval is unexpectedly long).

After that they never manage to connect again. To get them to be able to connect, the other side must also be restarted.

This has nothing to do with NAT etc as these are two devices with hardcoded addresses to each other on the same host. Presumably it's about some sort of connection state that is never cleared out.

Hello,

I'm currently implementing a custom implementation of the syncthing protocol and I noticed something strange with deleted files.

I know this may be a bug in my implementation, but I don't think I broke the protocol, at least according to the documentation.

I create a file on my side. Everything is fine. Then I delete it. Everything is fine, but I send this index update:

```
name: "small_new_logo2 (copie 1) (copie 1).png"
modified_s: 1490123996
deleted: true
version {
  counters {
    id: 12341524340436289198
    value: 2
  }
}
sequence: 1256
modified_ns: 235634803
Blocks {
  size: 3814
  hash: "\264]\013_G\030\243\024njt\014K24\313w\010<\370\036\355\265\022\241\2770\240L\324\345|"
}
```
Remark: I send blocks. This seems stupid, but the variable wasn't cleanup on my side when the file was deleted.
Syncthing delete the file, no problem.

Then, I add the same file again, and syncthing is stuck. The file is not added back, and I have this errors in logs:

```
(...)
[XXX] 20:23:12 INFO: Puller (folder "synctest", file "small_new_logo2 (copie 1) (copie 1).png"): shortcut: chmod: chmod /home/XXX/SyncTest/small_new_logo2 (copie 1) (copie 1).png: no such file or directory
[XXX] 20:23:12 INFO: Puller: shortcut: chmod /home/XXX/SyncTest/small_new_logo2 (copie 1) (copie 1).png: no such file or directory
[XXX] 20:23:12 INFO: Folder "synctest" isn't making progress. Pausing puller for 1m0s.
```
Sending a correct index update for a deleted file, without blocks, fix the issue.

Again, I know it's stupid to send blocks of a deleted file, it doesn't make sense. But syncthing should be able to handle the case, no ? Or the protocol definition should be updated to prevent client to send blocks ?

If needed I can try to make a PR with one of the "fix".

Apparently the default rate limit of zero (no limit) breaks on arm64. The cause chain seems to be:

- [we create a zero rate limiter](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/master/lib/connections/limiter.go#L68) (that `<` should be a `<=`, thanks to @AudriusButkevicius for noticing)
- [the zero rate is documented to drop all events](https://godoc.org/golang.org/x/time/rate#Limit)
- there is a bug (???) in the rate limiter package that makes this not actually happen, instead a zero rate limiter allows all events
- except, apparently on arm64 (???)

Removing and re-adding a folder causes a reset of the index for that folder and a rescan. Consider the following scenario, with two devices A and B:

- A and B are in sync
- A and B are disconnected
- A changes a couple of files, version vector gets bumped, let's say {A:42, B:36}
- A removes and re-adds the folder
- A rescans and assigns new version vectors with {A:1} to everything
- A and B connect
- B's older file will have a version vector like {A:40, B: 36}
- B's older files overwrite A's newer files (it's not a conflict)

Maybe not a super common scenario, but a folder can be removed by mistake and re-added, or because it's moved on disk, or for many other reasons.

Idea: should the short ID in the version vector not be based on our device ID, but instead a random ID assigned to the folder, e.g., our delta index ID?

Not seen myself, but reported:

```
INFO: Connection to ... closed: unmarshalling message: proto: wrong wireType = 2 for field BlockIndexes
```

It looks like the encoding of block indexes was changed in 0725e3af, maybe due to a newer or older version of the protobuf encoder, and this is an incompatibility.

```diff
func (m *BlockInfo) Reset()                    { *m = BlockInfo{} }
@@ -380,7 +383,7 @@ type FileDownloadProgressUpdate struct {
        UpdateType   FileDownloadProgressUpdateType `protobuf:"varint,1,opt,name=update_type,json=updateType,proto3,enum=protocol.FileDownloadProgressUpdateType" json:"update_type,omitempty"`
        Name         string                         `protobuf:"bytes,2,opt,name=name,proto3" json:"name,omitempty"`
        Version      Vector                         `protobuf:"bytes,3,opt,name=version" json:"version"`
-       BlockIndexes []int32                        `protobuf:"varint,4,rep,name=block_indexes,json=blockIndexes" json:"block_indexes,omitempty"`
+       BlockIndexes []int32                        `protobuf:"varint,4,rep,packed,name=block_indexes,json=blockIndexes" json:"block_indexes,omitempty"`
 }
```

(note addition of `packed`, which should anyway be the default in proto3)

```diff
@@ -1140,11 +1163,22 @@ func (m *FileDownloadProgressUpdate) MarshalTo(data []byte) (int, error) {
        }
        i += n3
        if len(m.BlockIndexes) > 0 {
-               for _, num := range m.BlockIndexes {
-                       data[i] = 0x20
-                       i++
-                       i = encodeVarintBep(data, i, uint64(num))
+               data5 := make([]byte, len(m.BlockIndexes)*10)
+               var j4 int
+               for _, num1 := range m.BlockIndexes {
+                       num := uint64(num1)
+                       for num >= 1<<7 {
+                               data5[j4] = uint8(uint64(num)&0x7f | 0x80)
+                               num >>= 7
+                               j4++
+                       }
+                       data5[j4] = uint8(num)
+                       j4++
                }
+               data[i] = 0x22
+               i++
+               i = encodeVarintBep(data, i, uint64(j4))
+               i += copy(data[i:], data5[:j4])
        }
        return i, nil
 }
```

(actual marshalling code changed, field type changing from `0` (varint) to `2` (Length-delimited	string, bytes, embedded messages, packed repeated fields))

The "Ignore Patterns" button is disabled, even if a .stignore file is present and contains patterns to be ignored. It worked on previous versions.

### Version Information

Syncthing Version: v0.14.17
OS Version: Mac OS X / Linux (ARM)
Browser Version: Safari

Let's say I add a folder containing subdirectories with movies in them. It scans and all is fine. I then add ignore patterns:

```
!*.mp4
*
```

I intend this to mean only sync the mp4s in the subdirectories, but that's of course not how it works in Syncthing. Nonetheless the things were already scanned, and I have a hunch that when someone now connects we'll send them an index entry for `foo/bar.mp4` (because it matches the unignore at the top) but not the `foo` entry (because it's ignored), resulting in an orphaned file and an error on the destination.

In syncthing 0.14.13 and earlier, on the receiving side, we'd have said "huh, weird" and created the directory and synced the file. It would have appeared as working, sort of, except new additions wouldn't be added because they're correctly ignored on the source.

This is a potential security issue, but one minor enough that I'm just going to report it here so that it's documented and we don't forget about it. If an attacker

1. controls another remote, already accepted device
2. can write to the local folder

they can cause an update for `foo/bar` on the remote device and with correct timing switch the directory `foo` into a symlink `foo -> /` locally, thus causing Syncthing to write to `/bar` instead.

But the situation is already quite dire when the attacker controls your device and one remote device, and this is only an escalation in the case where Syncthing runs as a different user than the attacker, but the attacker can still write to the same folder as Syncthing.

The correct solution requires `openat` which is currently (from Go) only supported on Linux.

It's not clear that a correct solution exists for Windows.

Syncing a **folder** with the read-only attribute set between Windows clients works as expected. However, when deleting the folder on one client, the other goes "Out of Sync" in the GUI with "access denied" in the Syncthing console.

The folder must then be manually deleted on the second machine (using explorer or "attrib" and "del" commands in the console.)

This seems similar to Issue #1610 only with folders rather than files.

Note: Windows sets the read-only attribute on folders automatically when you set a custom icon for said folder--that's how I initially discovered the issue. However, manually creating a read-only folder results in exactly the same behavior from Syncthing.

Syncthing Version: v0.14.11
OS Version: Windows 7

Syncthing overwrote a conflicting file during a sync without noticing the conflict.

I expected Syncthing to notice the file it was about to overwrite had not yet been seen through a local scan and either rename it, or create the new file with a "conflict" filename.

Syncthing Version: v0.4.11 both sides
OS Version: Windows 10 / FreeBSD 9.3 / Fedora 24

Steps:
1) Add a new file X on machine A (Windows 10).
2) Add a new file X on machine B (FreeBSD 9.3) with different content.
3) Rescan on machine A. Triggers sync to machine B.

Machine B overwrites file X without warning since it hasn't discovered it via a scan yet.
I've tested this between a few different OSes in different directions.
Other observations:
- Modifying existing files on both sides before a single rescan appears to work correctly.
- Deleting the test files then rescanning/recreating on both sides/rescanning appears to generate the expected conflict file.

It is slightly contrived I know, but it is more likely when using longer rescan intervals to conserve battery / IOPS. There is no safety net if multiple machines create a file with the same name within a rescan interval.

_**Syncthing Version**: v0.14.10
**OS Version**: Windows 7 / LinuxMint 13|17|18 / FreeBSD 10

---------------------------------

 **- what happened:**
SyncThing monitored over web interface and it showed 3/3 listeners(two relays and local IP).
I stopped one of relay server, then upgraded it to the latest version and restarted. 
Upgraded relay itself is working fine.
SyncThing showed 2/3 listeners regardless how long one ready to wait.
When relay was upgraded and restarted syncthing stuck on 2/3 listeners and upgraded relay does not show any connection from clients too ("numConnections": 0,)
After syncthing forcibly was restarted via web gui menu, syncthing found all relays again

 **- what you expected to happen instead:**
I assume that syncthing should query relay on reguar basis and reconnect to it automatically in case of network issue with relay or relay simply restarted.

 **- any steps to reproduce the problem:**
Precondition: running own latest relay (strelaysrv-~10+12) and discovery(stdiscosrv-linux-arm-v0.14.10+6) servers. Query to discovery and relays issued with certificate pinning (providing UUID of remote relay in URL). Relays and discovery server listening on non default ports.

Everything works fine until one of relays stopped for a period of time longer than 
specified in query url to relay (...pingInterval=1m0s&networkTimeout=2m0s...)
After that, syncthing will not automatically reconnect to relay that was restarted. 
The only restart of synthing can fix issue.

First, I think it somehow related to a new version of stRelay but it isn't (tried to run previous version with the same effect - if relay stopped for long period of time and started again, clients cant see restarted relay anymore until clients itself restarted)

For some unknown reason, I entered `syncthing /paths` instead of `syncthing -paths` at the command line for a user not currently running syncthing.

It seems that st ignores any arguments other than options, and started normally, creating files and certificates and launching the gui.

Options appear to be validated as expected. `syncthing -paths` and `syncthing --paths` are accepted and show the expected information.  `syncthing ---paths` and `syncthing -junk` respond as `syncthing -help`.

However, there seems to be no validation that the rest of the command line is empty apart from comments.

No great harm happened - just a few files to delete.

I consider this a minor, embarrassing bug.

Reload then works, of course. And on next startup we are fast enough for this not to happen. Probably depends on the browser being able to load quite rapidly when asked to.

We should delay starting the browser until we know the listener is up and running, by using a channel or some other magic (an event perhaps).

I just noticed my backup program (attic/borg backup) backing up a number of syncthing folders, which are called tmp-index-sorter.##### and live in the config directory. I understand these are db files enabling the delta-indexing algorithm. In the past I would ignore folders by placing a "cachedir.tag" file into folders I don't want backed up.
In this case I was puzzled by their naming scheme though- they are called "tmp*" -something , but don't seem to be more temporal than the actual database-folder. My initial thought was thus not to place the cachedir.tag -files there, since "tmp"-folders tend to get cleaned up at times (?!)
Also, there are quite a number of "tmp-index-sorter"-folders, and it looks untidy. O:-) At least much less tidy than I am used to from syncthing.
Wouldn't it make more sense to at least put all the index-related db-folders into an extra subfolder say $st_home/index/ ?

So I guess I am proposing both a naming-scheme change and a location change...

**TL;DR:** Seems like for some reason renaming of the updated binary from temp to `.exe` failed (maybe due to security software scan, or whatever...), but the original ST binary was already wiped (or renamed to `.old`. And thus node is effectively dead on next boot.

Syncthing should handle binary switching more fail-safe: verify valid access to the new binary before removing the old one, and/or revert back to old one if the new one can't be used.
Either way, avoid "floating on the air (RAM)" as much as possible.

Setup is one Linux machine running Syncthing, and one Windows machine, both running 0.14. Assume a rescan after each command.

Remove "test "
#### Windows

We process incoming index updates according to the ignore patterns, to filter out unwanted entries. When ignore patterns changed to allow files that were previously filtered out things would be OK on the next index exchange / reconnect. Currently, there is no new index exchange so the new ignore patterns don't get matched against the remote index data.

We need to either save all the data and process it differently, or as a workaround drop the delta index data when ignore patterns change.

### Version Information

Syncthing Version: v0.13.4
OS Version: Windows 10 / Windows (64 bit)
### What happened:

URL: `http://127.0.0.1:8384/rest/system/browse?`
RESPONSE: `["etc\\","extra\\","metadata\\"]`
EXPECTED: a list of drives?
BUG: it presents the contents of the Syncthing executable folder

URL: `http://127.0.0.1:8384/rest/system/browse?current=C:%5C` (5C = backslash)
RESPONSE: `["C:etc\\","C:extra\\","C:metadata\\"]`
EXPECTED: contents of `C:\` root folder
BUG: it presents the contents of the Syncthing executable folder, but with `C:` prepended

URL: `http://127.0.0.1:8384/rest/system/browse?current=C:%2F` (2F = forwardslash)
RESPONSE: `["C:etc\\","C:extra\\","C:metadata\\"]`
EXPECTED: contents of `C:\` root folder
BUG: it presents the contents of the Syncthing executable folder, but with `C:` prepended

URL: `http://127.0.0.1:8384/rest/system/browse?current=G:%5C`
RESPONSE: `["G:$RECYCLE.BIN\\","G:Steam\\","G:System Volume Information\\"]`
EXPECTED: `["G:\\$RECYCLE.BIN\\","G:\\Steam\\","G:\\System Volume Information\\"]`
BUG: it is missing the escaped backslash between the drive and folder name. This happens for all drive root folders, going one folder deeper and it returns the correct full paths.
### Summary
- `/rest/system/browse` api calls to all drive folders on Windows are missing an escaped backslash between the drive and folder name.
- `/rest/system/browse` calls to `C:\` in any form return as if they were the Syncthing exe folder.

Hi,

I work with a team of animators, and our Syncthing share has a huge, nested share structure that currently has about 80GB in it, and it's growing a little bit every day. 
I don't know how difficult this would be to make happen (I imagine very), but there have been a couple times in working with Syncthing with a team that I have had to deal with infinite directory loops. Oftentimes they are a result from erring on some Syncthing share algebra, but the fact that it's happened twice in the past couple months could be cause for concern. In those instances, a popup warning that lets us know something along the lines of "Continuing with what you are doing could result in an infinite directory loop!" would have been really nice to keep us from making a that terrible mistake.

If you can't pull the directory structure at share creation, then maybe while it's starting its initial sync, run some pattern recognition that kills the sync process for the affected shares? This might help a lot since not all of my people are very technically inclined. Just a thought. Thanks!

When I change the ignore list entry to the following the warning won't occur after a restart.
`.config/syncthing`
### What I expect

The warning shouldn't occur when I'm syncing `~` and I ignored `/.config/syncthing`, just as with `.config/syncthing`.
### Steps to reproduce
1. Sync your home directory
2. Watch the configuration sync warning appear
3. Stop syncthing
4. Add `.config/syncthing` to your ignore list
5. Start syncthing
6. Make sure the configuration sync warning doesn't appear
7. Stop syncthing
8. Append `.config/syncthing` with `/`
9. Start syncthing
10. Watch the configuration sync warning appear
### Additonal

I haven't testet if the configuration files actually get synced with `/.config/syncthing`, they won't with `.config/syncthing`. Could be that only the configuration sync check is missing a rule.
Edit: I've testet the `/.config/syncthing` entry, as I expected the rule works as it should, the folder isn't getting synced. It's just the warning message that is missing a rule for that case.
### Version Information

Syncthing Version: v0.13.2
OS Version: Archlinux
Currently these are generated using the non-cryptographic RNG, limiting their total entropy to at most 64 bits even though they look longer. That's wrong.
Currently these are generated using the non-cryptographic RNG, limiting their total entropy to at most 64 bits even though they look longer. That's wrong.

Syncthing sets the Last-Modified header on static assets to the time at which the config was last committed. However, it sets a local time, whereas the docs for `http.TimeFormat` specify that the time must be UTC.

This can result in a Last-Modified time in the future for timezones ahead of GMT, or a time before the config was committed for timezones behind GMT.

This is probably partially responsible for the reports of the UI showing "Unknown Device" with an empty folder list when people upgrade to 0.13. I say "partially" because I know there have been reports from people ahead of GMT, so something else is at play as well here....

See [here](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/4bc2b3f3690c755a8ffb22862915e286bdc24702/cmd/syncthing/gui.go#L1257), [here](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/4bc2b3f3690c755a8ffb22862915e286bdc24702/cmd/syncthing/gui.go#L1300), and [here](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/4bc2b3f3690c755a8ffb22862915e286bdc24702/cmd/syncthing/gui.go#L301).

Even with a temp file in place containing correct data, that data is redownloaded again. Reproducible by locking a file (on Mac, or immutable attribute on Linux, something else on Windows maybe) so that a temp file can be created but the final rename can't happen. Watch it download and re-download for each attempt...
If we fail to rename a file (the last step when pulling it), the temp file is removed. It should instead be kept around as usual so we can reuse it.

Interesting issue I just noticed.  There are two ways of sharing a folder with a device:  1) by editing the folder and selecting the device OR 2) editing the device and selecting the folder.

Method 1 works fine, the folder is shared and the list of shared folders shows up in the list on the device menu.  However, Method 2 does not work.  In fact, the folders that have been shared via Method 1 do not show up as selected in the device menu.  See this image:  https://imgur.com/TpKo87j

Further, when folders are added via Method 2, they do not update in the list.  I selected all of the folders to share via the device menu and there is no update.  See this image:  https://imgur.com/TpKo87j

Thus, there appears to be a syncing issue between folders shared and the device menu folder selection.

I'm running syncthing on a few Ubuntu 12 and 14 machines and have no problems with crashes.  But I have one Ubuntu 16 machine where syncthing is crashing at seemingly random times.  I'm including all the output from the crash that displayed in the terminal window.  If I need to provide any further information please let me know and I will get it.

[syncthing-0.12.23-crash.txt](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/files/253022/syncthing-0.12.23-crash.txt)

Syncthing Version: v0.12.23
OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04
By creating an infinitely large temp file for the binary, for example. As reported privately by Sebastian Py. Thanks Sebastian!

By changing the JSON response from Github, the attacker can claim that a newer version is available but in reality point to an older version of Syncthing. Since the verification is only that the binary is correctly signed by the release team, the "upgrade" will be accepted. As reported by Sebastian Py - thanks Sebastian!

Syncthing Version: master
When two files are removed and the first path is a prefix of the second path, the local and global count are incorrectly updated. E.g. If Syncthing-inotify performs `scan?folder=default&sub=foo/bar&sub=foo/bar2` because the files `bar` and `bar2` are removed, the file count is reduced by 3 instead of 2. I traced it back to the fact that we use a [`batch`](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/29fa05ae0580e9a707171af7f0b00de6b92a5be8/lib/model/model.go#L1486) array instead of a map, which means the array we pass to updateLocals can contain duplicates. This confuses the intermediate counting we do in sizeTracker.

This could cause a panic: in [set.go](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/29fa05ae0580e9a707171af7f0b00de6b92a5be8/lib/db/set.go#L84)

Lately on my Raspberry pi2 I noticed a few "panic files" in the syncthing configuration folder. 
Operation resumed transparently which is why I did not notice on the spot.

For the time being, I have no idea about triggering condition. It happened both with 0.12.21 and 0.12.22.

Running syncthing-inotify and syncthing 0.12.19 on FreeBSD-11.

Until recently we were happily using rsync to update a syncthing distribution pool in the freebsd.org cluster.  We rsync from the source-of-truth into the pool, syncthing-inotify notices the changes and informs syncthing.  Syncthing then fans out the data nicely.  All the syncthing nodes are a mesh of peers, the rsync forces them to converge if there's a problem.

After our change from 0.12.13 to 0.12.19 we are now seeing dropped updates.   I provoked an update by deleting several directory trees and updating the indexes and signatures.  When the rsync happened, the inotify logs look correct and it appears that syncthing was correctly informed.

```
# touch index.txt ; touch *.sig
.... 
[OK] 00:55:00 Syncthing is indexing change in admin-built: [amd64_10.txt.sig amd64_11.txt.sig amd64_9.txt.sig i386_10.txt.sig i386_11.txt.sig ia64_10.txt.sig index.txt index.txt.sig sparc64_10.txt.sig]
```

The line in syncthing-inotify's log appears to correctly show that syncthing has received the correct notifications and has acknowledge them all correctly.

However, the result is this on the master (the mesh peer receiving the updates):

```
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing  3421 Mar 17 23:53 index.txt
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing   512 Mar 17 23:53 index.txt.sig
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing   512 Mar 17 23:53 amd64_9.txt.sig
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing   512 Mar 17 23:53 amd64_10.txt.sig
```

But the rest of the mesh has:

```
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing  3421 Mar 17 23:53 index.txt
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing   512 Mar 17 23:48 index.txt.sig
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing   512 Mar 17 23:53 amd64_9.txt.sig
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing   512 Mar 17 23:53 amd64_10.txt.sig
```

The problematic file is "index.txt.sig". 

The gui reports everything is in sync.  If I hit a 'rescan all' on the master, then the missing changes are discovered and the mesh resyncs. 

.stignore on the "master" mesh peer looks like this:

```
// rsync in-flight transfers
// eg: foo.txz is transferred as .foo.txz.23yXh3
.*
```

Another example, this time not using rsync at all.  This is directly in the monitored file system area.

```
syncthing@syncthing.nyi:/home/syncthing/built % touch foo.txt foo.txt.sig
syncthing@syncthing.nyi:/home/syncthing/built % ls -lrtT foo*
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing  0 Mar 18 01:02:34 2016 foo.txt
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing  0 Mar 18 01:02:34 2016 foo.txt.sig
...
[OK] 01:02:34 Syncthing is indexing change in admin-built: [foo.txt foo.txt.sig]
```

and on the peers:

```
root@syncthing.ysv:~syncthing/built # ls -lrtT foo*
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing  0 Mar 18 01:02:34 2016 foo.txt
```

foo.txt.sig didn't even arrive. GUI reports all peers 100% in sync.

Then I hit the 'rescan' button for the admin-built collection, and re-checked the peers:

```
root@syncthing.ysv:~syncthing/built # ls -lrtT foo*
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing  0 Mar 18 01:05:18 2016 foo.txt.sig
-rw-r--r--  1 syncthing  syncthing  0 Mar 18 01:05:18 2016 foo.txt
```

Is there some magic involving suffixes that I'm not aware of?  Perhaps there's a prefix/suffix bug in notification handlers inside syncthing?

What should I do next to track this down?

PS: If I don't use a common prefix, eg: "foo.txt and foo.sig" instead of "foo.txt and foo.txt.sig" then it works.

In my mind, the bug is that STGUIASSETS should no longer point to the same hierachy that we compile in, and that the behavior is different when overriding vs when not. It used to be very simple (assuming $PATH has been requested):
1. $STGUIASSETS/$PATH
2. Compiled in asset $PATH

Now we're instead looking for
1. $STGUIASSETS/$PATH
2. Compiled in asset $THEME/$PATH
3. Compiled in asset default/$PATH

I think it would be cleaner if we instead looked for
1. $STGUIASSETS/$THEME/$PATH
2. Compiled in asset $THEME/$PATH
3. $STGUIASSETS/default/$PATH
4. Compiled in asset default/$PATH

Then we'd get back the old behavior of just being able to override the whole hierarchy and then hack on the dark theme or whatever as @lkwg82 also mentions. A (small) complication is that the theme selector would need to pick up themes present both in the compiled in assets and in the potential overridden assetsDir.

From a development point of view, I think pointing STGUIASSETS at the gui dir in the source checkout should result in it working exactly as normal, except that anything in there can be overridden regardless of theme etc. It's just that I haven't noticed this is not the case because I haven't done nay GUI dev work lately :)

I noticed this issue when trying to share SyncThing configuration on a dual boot system. Both Windows and Linux have the SyncThing config folder symbolically linked to a folder on a shared partition.

The synced folder is also being linked to on Linux and Windows each with a symbolic link ~/SyncedFolder.

On Windows this is parsed with no issue. On Linux this does not work with an error saying the symbolic link is not a folder. The error does not occur if the full home path is specified - e.g. /home/username/SyncedFolder.

So issue seems to stem when parsing ~ when the destination folder is a symbolic link to the synced folder. The full error is "/home/username/SyncedFolder: not a directory" when the path specified is ~/SyncedFolder. I've confirmed that the symbolic link was set up correctly under Linux.

The connection / latency check in osutil doesn't use the proxy dialer, so it fails all relays with "connection refused" in the test phase. The actual relay code does use the proxy dialer, but that doesn't help.

Wherever we build glob patterns based on existing file names we need to take care of the fact that they can contain things like `[-]` which gets interpreted as a broken character range.

Probably we need a well tested utility function to build these patterns, or use something other than globbing.

As noted in #2598. Setting the required percentage to zero disables the percentage check. But we also check for each file that there is space for the temp file. But if the temp file already exists this can fail. We should either skip if the temp file already exists or, at the very least, skip the check if the required space is set to zero.

(Apart from this scenario, there may be valid cases where the disk space check just plain doesn't give accurate results and we should let the user override it.)

I found a curious behaviour when deleting directories and creating symbolic links.

Consider two machines One and Two. In One I make a directory A with a file a and a directory B with the same file a and another file b:

> ## 1
>

> A:
> a
> B:
> a b

I wait until both machines are synchronized. Later I remove directory A and replace it by a symbolic link to B

> ## 2
> 
>  One:~$ rm -r A; ln -s B A; ls -R 
>   A:
>   a b
>   B:
>   a b

Synchronization fails at Two when it tries to delete A because the directory is not empty.

> ## 3
> 
> Two:~$ ls -R 
> A:
> a
> B:
> a b

To allow synchronization to complete, I remove the directory A

> ## 4
> 
> Two:~$ rm -r A; ls B
> a b

After synchronization completes A becomes a symbolic link in machine Two, as expected, but with the undesired consequence that in the process file a disappeared from directory B in both machines, whereas it was deleted from directory A in machine Two where it was not linked to directory B.

> ## 5
> 
> One:~$ ls -R
> A:
> b
> B:
> b
> 
> Two:~$ ls -R
> A:
> b
> B:
> b

> ## 2bis
> 
>  One:~$ rm -r A; sleep 120; ln -s B A; ls -R 
>   A:
>   a b
>   B:
>   a b
> ## 3bis
> 
> Two:~$ ls -R 
> A:
> a b

If the user hasn't made any changes to the configuration in a month or more, and they upgrade Syncthing, the previous config file is deleted by the [clean-up routine](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/db4f23f3771e56184a93474f1939508044cb1ce0/cmd/syncthing/main.go#L1071).

Presumably this isn't desired behaviour - maybe the config upgrade routine could timestamp the old file, so as not to invoke the wrath of the clean-up routine.

Syncthing cannot write/update .stignore on Android due to failed chmod operations.
In mode.go we use CreateAtomic that relies on chmod operations which are not permitted on Android. See the following error:

```
[BH4HG] 03:33:26 WARNING: Saving .stignore: chmod /storage/1AF9-2A10/DCIM/.syncthing.tmp.190076736: operation not permitted
```

We set the non-saved config attribute `Invalid` to "duplicate folder id" or "no directory configured" for those two errors when loading the config. We propagate this to the UI so the folder _looks_ stopped and shows the error in question. But we never even look at the `Invalid` attribute anywhere else in the code, so the folder is in fact running as usual and doing scans and whatnot.

We need to have `Invalid` actually invalidate a folder, and do it in a way that doesn't get revived by `CheckFolderHealth`. It should be used only for nonrecoverable errors - config error, or potentially the new checksum mismatch error.

Alternatively we could just refuse to load the config when it's broken in this manner, have `CheckFolderHealth` handle the missing path case (it probably already does) and remove the `Invalid` thing altogether?

I've been noticing troublesome behaviour lately that started to occur since upgrading to 0.12. I have a repository that is shared with my own PC (Windows 8.1 x64 running Syncthing 0.12.2) and another remote PC (Windows 7 x64 running Syncthing 0.12.2). Both machines are running Syncthing through SyncTrayzor 1.0.29.

Sometimes, when I change the name of a folder that contains files/more folders on my PC, Syncthing on the other PC begins to completely redownload all the files into the new folder and then deletes the old folder and its contents afterwards, instead of creating a new folder and moving the existing files there. The same happens to file renames.

The same goes for changing files, instead of downloading only the changed blocks, Syncthing on the remote PC downloads the entire file and replaces the old one.

This appears to happen randomly as I've seen a few occassions where changing folder/file names does gets handled as expected. I wonder if anyone else has noticed something similar happening. Would it maybe help for me to remake my Syncthing repositories?

Currently it takes the first file it finds called `syncthing` and uses that as the binary to upgrade to. After #2440 this became the ufw config file, which is entirely wrong.

Luckily that file doesn't pass the signature check so the upgrade was aborted rather than blowing away the binary for the user...

The `-gui-address` command-line parameter no longer accepts a scheme in v0.12, complains of "too many colons".

See IRC log:

```
<canton7> it seems that v0.12 doesn't like having 'http://' or 'https://' in the -gui-address command-line parameter?
<calmh> okay
<canton7> is that an intended change, or an (unintended?) artefact of something else?
<calmh> too many colons etc
<canton7> yeah
<calmh> i think unintended
<calmh> i don't remember doing something about it intentionally
<calmh> but i do remember changing how we handle overrides of those things from the command line
<calmh> so i probably broke something
<canton7> it would make my life amazing again if I can force https, even if the user hasn't checked that box in the settings (otherwise I'm playing a bit of a redirection guessing game) :D
<calmh> you can always use https anyway, you won't get a redirect to http from it
<calmh> but yes, that's supposed to work
<canton7> I vaguely recall there being a gotcha there, but can't remember what it was
<canton7> (helpful I know..)
<calmh> right
<calmh> so if that option is given, we just pretend that was the value that was stored as listen port in the config
<calmh> but we don't store it that way in the config, and we have a separate tls flag there
<calmh> so that's broken
<calmh> we shoudl chop off the scheme, like we did before
<calmh> i changed the config handling for other reasons a few commits back and broke this then
```

Not sure if it is a bug or not, but it's better to write it down:
- I am running into the free space limit and I get these messages: `[TYZZZ] INFO: Skipping folder dokumente scan due to folder error: insufficient free space`
- Due to the limit currently my sync stucks at 59 % (at that box where the limit has been hit)
- I have deleted the big file, that is being pulled on another node
- Syncing stays at 59 %

---

After restarting syncthing it recognizes that there is not more file to pull; that's fine. But because of the free space limit it keeps stopping that particular folder, so it does not delete the file, hence it keeps stuck.

When trying Syncthing 0.11.26, the first screen (http://127.0.0.1:8080/) has these problems:
1. English reports as expanded, when it should default to collapsed since the list is collapsed by default.
   If I expand and collapse it, it reports as expected.
   I think the fix here is to just default to aria-expanded="false", not true.
2. Upon first loading the page, Actions doesn't report as collapsed even though I can expand it. It only gets aria-expanded="false" when I expand and collapse it for the first time.
   That, too, should default to aria-expanded="false".
3. After adding a folder, there's no indication that the folder is expandable. If I press enter on one, I get more info such as the path.

I am running `v0.12.0-beta2+10-g375c9dd` and I discovered an issue according to local discovery. I have two nodes in my local network and they seem to connect through the global discovery machinery (via upnp port forwarding) instead. After disabling upnp in my router they connect through my local network. 

I remember this issue has been there some time ago; maybe a regression?
I broke this in 36ac757 as we no longer use the "overridden" config, but the actual on disk config.

Syncthing should print an error message if an `.stignore` file is broken. This includes cases where an `#include` points to a non-existing file. It might also include other cases, e.g., invalid patterns.

Currently, it seems that Syncthing ignores errors when loading `.stignore` files ([model.go:1186](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/master/lib/model/model.go#L1186)). The comment says this is because there might not be an `.stignore` file. We should differentiate between this condition and actual errors in the `.stignore` file.

If an `.stignore` file turns out to be broken, the safest thing to do is not touch the folder at all until the error is fixed. Otherwise, data loss might occur (e.g., if the user deletes a file that (s)he thought was ignored, and the deletion is propagated).

Forum discussion: https://forum.syncthing.net/t/useful-stignore-patterns/1175/51

I had an Amazon EC2 instance with a ~36.6 GB folder residing within it. I had syncthing running as master-slave from one instance to another. A configuration issue on the slave caused me to need to clone the master again to replace the current slave. In doing so, the ~36.6 GB folder would be retained and would be exactly the same on both devices. I also deleted the Syncthing folder in LocalAppData on the new slave instance to guarantee they wouldn't have the same IDs.

**What happened**

The disk space on the slave instance only had ~25 GB left. Syncthing on the slave instance claimed that the entire folder was out of sync, which seems plausible because at this point both instances had been running and there might be file metadata inconsistencies. However, the slave instance refused to sync the metadata because I didn't have an _extra_ ~36.6 GB left, even though clearly the entire amount, twice, didn't need to be synced. 

So the issue is that Syncthing refused to operate on the slave instance because I didn't have enough space for the second copy of a directory that already existed.

Of course, deleting the folder on the slave instance and resyncing worked.

I took this screenshot after another restart, so I don't have the Insufficient Disk Space errors showing here. ![Error](http://i.imgur.com/FsL9RTz.png)

created by github.com/syncthing/syncthing/lib/discover.(*Discoverer).StartLocal

It's fairly clear cut but a little bit annoying to fix cleanly. Since relaying is disabled, we have `var relaySvc *relay.Svc` in main which is nil, that we then pass to the discovery service. But the discovery service takes a `discovery.relayStatusProvider` interface. Since we're passing a _variable_ that is nil, and not a nil _literal_, the other side gets a "typed nil" interface, so the check in there for `relayStatusProvide == nil` ends up being false even though the interface contains a nil pointer.

The cleanest way is probably

```
if relaySvc == nil {
    disc = discover.NewDiscoverer(myID, opts.ListenAddress, nil)
} else {
    disc = discover.NewDiscoverer(myID, opts.ListenAddress, relaySvc)
}
```

in main.go, but goddamn that looks like crap...

The updated machine says "Global State 597461 items, Local State 492169 items" while the other machine says "Global State 1018928 items, Local State 1020770 items." The numbers are gradually getting closer, but it seems like it is going through iterations of seeing changes, syncing them, seeing more changes, syncing those, etc.

When each machine has completed a local scan and discovered which files it has, I would expect the other machine to acquire the full list of changed files in minutes, not days.

**Question:** Is Syncthing using a proper address for IPv6 mulitcast?

**Background:**
I'm working with @dapperstout on the Swift implementation of syncthing. Because I'm having trouble getting IPv6 multicast to work, I posted a question about it on stack overflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/31574247/gcdasyncudpsocket-cannot-get-udp-multicast-over-ipv6-to-work?noredirect=1#comment51108878_31574247. I don't know too much about IPv6 yet, but on stack overflow it is claimed that the Syncthing multicast address (ff32::5222), as specified in https://github.com/syncthing/specs/blob/master/DISCOVERYv2.md, is reserved for future use (referring to http://www.iana.org/assignments/ipv6-multicast-addresses/ipv6-multicast-addresses.xhtml#unicast-multicast-group-ids). 

Could someone with enough knowledge on this have a look at it? If this is a bug in the specification, it would be good to fix it.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a new folder, but don't restart Syncthing
2. Edit that folder's settings, and click 'Ignore Patterns'

Observe that the request fails with a 500 ("Folder foo.bar does not exist"), and that you can now not click on _any_ 'Ignore Patterns' buttons until the browser is refreshed.

In the Actions/Advanced Configuration dialog is impossible to show parameters related to the folder containing dot character in the name (by click on it). For example "test.fr".

This isn't problem of main dashboard. There it's working.

Related to v0.11.12 - v0.11.15 (latest).

Syncthing 0.11.14, Windows.

Steps to repro:

1) Add folder using the web UI
2) Restart syncthing as prompted
3) New folder does not appear in the web UI, and is not present in `config.xml`.

By the looks of it, the browser correctly posts the new folder config, and a subsequent get of `rest/system/config` retrieves it. However, it's lost on restart.

# Scenario I was going to add a folder. First I wrote a folder path in the text field, but never finished the configuration. Later I reopened the modal window, Safari autocompleted my path based on previous value. I was satisfied, stopped writing and applied the settings. But it was not obvious that only characters written by hand was applied (characters written by Safari was not included in the javascript variable). This is dangerous, it might share files not intended to be shared. This is a common bug shared by other projects, I have seen it before in Safari-AngularJS solutions. # Expected behaviour Directories provided by autocompleted path should have been used instead of parent or grandparent. # Revisions and vendoring Mac OS X Yosmite, syncthing v0.11.13 and Safari v8.0.6 # Screenshots # Poor-mans-solution If it's not possible to prohibit, then maybe a alert window should pop-up verifying the most dangerous values before it's applied to the rest of the system.
If you hit the close button instead of the save button, it still saves every change you made.

The setguid bit on new folders created by syncthing is not preserved when those new folders are created as children of a folder with the setguid bit enabled.

My system is Debian Jessie 8.1 and I'm running Syncthing v0.11.10 (from the debian release channel).

I expected the setgid bit to be preserved as it is when using `mkdir` from the command line. This is a problem as I have a shared folder between multiple users all in a common group and I would like to keep all newly created folders owned by that group. As it stands, I have a top folder called `music` with permissions `drwxrwsr-x+`, when Syncthing creates a sub-folder `Queen` that folder does not inherit setguid and instead has permissions `drwxrwxr-x+` (note that it should be `drwxrwsr-x+`). This is a problem as when Syncthing creates a sub-folder of `Queen`, `Queen/Jazz` that folder now has syncthing as it's group as opposed to `media`, the shared group I would like. Now other users cannot access `Queen/Jazz`.

I have tried creating folders and files on the command line under different user accounts and everything is working as I expect so I'm confident I've set up my permissions, groups and ACLs correctly and hence why I suspect this is an issue in Syncthing.

I may also be able to submit a pull request to fix this but I would greatly appreciate a few pointers towards the relevant areas of code that I should look at.

Hi!
Noticed strange behavior when unmount/mount external HDD:
- Folder on a node B synchronized with folder on external HDD on node A
- external HDD on node A have been unmounted
- Folder on node B was changed (for example, I delete 1 file)
- mount HDD again to node A
- deleted file appears on node B again
  So, seems like when external HDD mounted again, all files on it counted as new and are being synced back to other nodes, even if they were modified/deleted previously.
  I noticed, that when I delete file on node B during external drive was disconnected from node A, Syncthing on node A get that (I see "delete file <..>" in folder status on node A), but when external HDD mounted back, that change doesn't being applied.

short question:
Is there a special reason, why it's not possible to edit an Ignore Pattern list from a computers browser, where the syncthing install is not local, or can this be considered as a bug?

long explanation:
-Computer A with installed syncthing v0.11.9, Windows (64 bit), FireFox 38.0.5 browser and tab with URL http://ip_to_computer_B/ pointing to computer B.

-Computer B with installed syncting v0.11.9, Mac OS X (32 bit)

-ip_to_computer_A is 192.168.1.10:8384
-ip_to_computer_B is 192.168.1.20:8384

When trying to edit the Ignore Pattern list of any configured and already saved folder from computer B using the browser from computer A, the Ignore Patterns-button is greyed out and not clickable.
(glitchy behaviour btw: sometimes the button clickable, but with no result other than greying that button out after the click)

What I expected to happen: 
Ignore Patterns List would open up and be editable in the browsers window.

When on computer B with same browserversion, using the webgui via URL ip_to_computer_B or 127.0.0.1:8384 everything works as expected (list opens and user can edit).

Summary:
its not possible to edit an Ignore Pattern list of another syncthing installation from another computer in the LAN. Only from the Computer, where the synthing installation is local.
Other settings, such as File Versioning or Pull Order are editable.

Let user change the whole configuration of syncthing from any computer.

When entering a large enough value (I tried `60000000000`) into the rescanIntervalS property of a shared folder, Syncthing will crash during startup with the following message:

```
 panic: invalid argument to Int63n
```

Which is presumably triggered by [this piece of code](https://golang.org/src/math/rand/rand.go#L61) when generating a random number during startup to decide when to perform the initial scan of the folder. (I'm guessing, I don't know Go and I don't know how Syncthing handles startup)

This issue can be reproduced by directly editing config.xml or by changing the value through the web UI, and will be triggered upon the next start up.

I've only tested this on v0.11.9, Linux (64 bit).

Thread where I first reported this problem: https://forum.syncthing.net/t/deleted-file-causing-issues/3039

Setup:
- syncthing v0.11.7
- 2 devices ('server' and 'desktop') sharing one directory
- only local discovery (UPnP, global discovery are disabled)
- 2 Android ST devices in the same network, but no sharing with the other 2 devices

Problem: after some time, the 'server' device stops receiving local announcements from the 'desktop' device

How to reproduce:
- Start ST on both devices, synchronizing works between them
- Switch off 'desktop' device, wait some time
- Switch on 'desktop', start ST => no contact to 'server' device could be established

https://forum.syncthing.net/t/server-stops-receiving-local-announcements-from-other-devices/2896

I get a SIGILL when shutting down syncthing with CTRL+C or strangely when hitting Exit in the Android App running on a different System.

syncthing runs on an ARM v5 CPU on a NAS. 

When stopping syncthing with CTRL+C I get the SIGILL. When I connect my Android Phone with the Android App and tap on "Exit" in the App the syncthing instance running on the NAS gets also the SIGILL.

When adding a folder on a volume with NTFS Deduplication enabled, deduped files are incorrectly skipped by the scanner. Files that are still pending deduplication are processed as expected. Folders are also processed as normal. A bit of digging indicates that os.Lstat on a deduped file has a FileMode containing ModeSymLink. Looking at the Read function in [symlink_windows.go](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/master/internal/symlinks/symlink_windows.go#L104), the type of reparse point is available in reparseData.reparseTag, which should allow for correctly handling the condition. A quick reference to the tag values is available in [smbfsctl.h](https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/fs/cifs/smbfsctl.h#L100). Of interest are: - IO_REPARSE_TAG_DEDUP = 0x80000013 - IO_REPARSE_TAG_SYMLINK = 0xA000000C - IO_REPARSE_TAG_MOUNT_POINT = 0xA0000003 (may be related to #1830) - More info about [Reparse Points](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa365511%28v=vs.85%29.aspx) and supported operations For reference, it is possible to query a reparse point's tag and data with fsutil reparsepoint query PATH_TO_FILE. This even works across SMB shares with UNC paths.

Cluster: 5 Windows machines (x32 and x64), 10.30 and later 11, star topology, shared folder with 5 midsized (200mb) files in different folders. Files updates about twice at week from any node. Time at nodes the same.

I update 1 file on node. Syncing begins. Looking console at remote node i see: "cant delete folder because not empty". WTF?! There are no any folder operations, only 1 file update! Restarting remote node. Remote syncthing restarts and deletes folder. Next move - its syncing back to my machine and remove this folder, destroying my data and makes me sick, finally removing this folder from cluster!

As per:
https://forum.syncthing.net/t/ignore-pattern-modification-and-override-changes/2531/12

```

 1. Create an empty sync folder pair on node A & B. Check folder master on A. By default the there is no .stignore file so there is no ignore pattern on either A or B.
 2. Create empty file Test1.txt on A. Wait for a while, it will appear on B. This is normal.
 3. Create the .stignore file on A and put "/Test1.txt" in it. This makes A ignore the file created in last step.
 4. Open Test1.txt on A and type in something. Save and close it.
 5. Create empty file Test2.txt on A.
 6. Wait for a while and Test2.txt appears on B. Test1.txt on B is still empty. This is normal as Test1.txt is in A's ignore list now so A will not transfer any content update of Test1.txt. This proves the ignore pattern on A is correct and working.
 7. Delete Test1.txt from A. Wait for a while.
 8. The Override Change button appears on A. Click the Out of Sync link on A will list Test1.txt. This is normal as B has Test1.txt but A though it don't have(because ignored).
 9. Click the override button on A. It will disappear for one second but back again in the next second. You can click the override button again and again, it always comes back. The Test1.txt is always listed as out of sync. The Test1.txt file never get deleted on B. This is not normal, and this is the issue I'm talking about.
 10. Create empty file Test3.txt on **B**.
 11. Now on A the out of sync link shows both Test1.txt and Test3.txt.
 12. Click the override button on A. Test3.txt disappears from out of sync link and B's folder. This is normal.
```

Syncthing doesn't delete old files with "simple file versioning" on WinXP, and deletes correct with "Staggered File Versioning".
On Linux (Ubuntu) simple versioning works fine - keeps only two old versions (as I set).

`syncthing -upgrade` works, but the button should be shown? Perhaps with a different note or color or something as it's a major upgrade. We should probably get this out as a last maintenance release on v0.10.

If two folders both have the ID "default" in the config, we rename them to "default~1" and "default~2". But tilde isn't allowed in folder IDs, and the user can't change folder IDs in the GUI, so it's kinda impossible to recover gracefully from.

Granted, they shouldn't be able to get in this state without editing the config manually to start with, but still...

If a device resets it's index (i.e. the files are removed or corrupt for whatever reason), and files are not in sync with the cluster, we should take care not to overwrite them when it rejoins the cluster. Differences should be marked and handled as conflicts.

I was syncing some files from a Linux machine to the Windows 8 host, then deleted some of those files again.

The log on the Windows machine turned up these errors:

```
[GUEL3] 22:27:05 INFO: Puller (folder "Photos", file "2012\\08\\04\\124620.jpeg")
: delete: remove C:\Users\Fred\Photos\2012\08\04\124620.jpeg: access denied
[GUEL3] 22:27:05 INFO: Puller (folder "Photos", file "2012\\08\\04\\124628.jpeg")
: delete: remove C:\Users\Fred\Photos\2012\08\04\124628.jpeg: access denied
[GUEL3] 22:27:05 WARNING: Folder "Photos" isn't making progress - check logs for
possible root cause. Pausing puller for 1m0s.
```

I could delete those files manually using the Windows explorer, but trying to run del in a cmd window gave an error too:

```
> del C:\Users\Fred\Photos\2012\08\04\124628.jpeg
C:\Users\Fred\Photos\2012\08\04\124628.jpeg
Access is denied.
```

Turns out, that on Windows, you cannot simply delete files having the `READONLY` flag set. See the discussion here: https://github.com/golang/go/issues/9606

Basically, you would have to remove the `read-only` attribute prior to trying call os.remove.

Hi, I managed to crash syncthing 8-) panic log Windows 7 64bit, syncthing v0.11.0-beta4 (go1.4.2 windows-386 default) ~~Probably caused by calling /rest/system/config~~ ... or not, it happens every time when I start daemon, right after connection to ~~older daemon~~ is initiated. edit no2: And did I mentioned that it connects to _itself_? ``` [WEVFD] 09:29:08 INFO: Established secure connection to XXX-XX-XXX at 10.148.1.55:61618-ip:22000 ``` where `10.148.1.55` is address of this very machine that has daemon crashing. There is no other ST daemon running around.

And when touch screen is used to move QR code to be fully visible, it's the background page which moves, and not the overlay with the QR code.

This was using the web interface (Bootstrap) on an older small Android phone. On a modern phablet, it works well.

![2015-04-07-syncthing-qrcode-small-screen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1004261/7029715/a66b111e-dd2d-11e4-8767-d87f14585ade.png)

I have that message on all available Macs although all of them are configured to use IPv6.

While debugging iOS version, I've found that IPv6 multicasting on iOS requires to configure IPV6_MULTICAST_IF and IPV6_ADD_MEMBERSHIP with an exact interface index set, i.e. passing 0 will not work.

I think that should do the trick on OS X too.
